column12:
This is an important principle, but it has some gaps.

Archaeologists need to consider archaeological sites and archaeological collections, including all the digital associated records they produce, as equally important resources. Currently, sites are considered more important than collections for stewardship. This has got to stop (seems to be mostly perpetuated in academia) since the existing collections may be the primary resource for future research as it gets more and more difficult to investigate sites as is currently done.
column14:
This is an important principle, but it has a gap.

Academics need to be taught that most archaeology is now paid for through taxpayer dollars (federal grants are also supported by tax dollars).  Therefore, archaeologists must be accountable to the public for the proper use of those dollars.  Consultation is critical whether formal or informal.
column18:
This is an important principle, but it has a few gaps.

Other "publics" that need education and outreach are developers, private land owners, and granting organizations. Granting organizations, in particular, don't seem to value the responsibilities and activities associated with taking care of and accessing/researching/interpreting collections as much as sites. Both are part of the archaeological record and both need support.
column20:
This is an important principle, but it has some problems and gaps.

Many archaeologists, especially academics, do not understand that the associated records, as defined in 36 CFR 79 for federal collections and in state/tribal/local laws, are the property of the landowner, now usually a government agency. The records, including analytical data, must be curated as part of the archaeological collection owned by the property owner (in cases of private land owners, hopefully transferred to a repository or an agency by via a Deed of Gift), even if no objects were recovered.  The text in the 3rd sentence -- "no legal restrictions or strong countervailing interests" -- is not adequately explained.  I just explained the "legal restrictions" that are very prevalent out there. What are examples of "strong countervailing interests"?

Who are "others" in the last sentence??  Really should be "the public".

Need to discuss intellectual property rights either in this principle or in a separate one.
column22:
This is an important principle, but it has some gaps.  The emphasis on publication is a bit much when the "other means" of "public reporting" aren't stated. They could be museum exhibits (either in a repository or online); public programming, i.e., lectures, teaching kits; or wayside signs on a trail, among other things.  The emphasis on "publication" caters to academics, which are not the majority of the archaeologists out there now. Most CRM and gov't archaeologists don't publish since there are no business incentives to do so.

It needs to be explicit that the research can be of either sites or collections!  

The 2nd sentence is problematic.  Suggest something like "The associated records -- documents and analytical materials on which all forms of public reporting are based--, should be curated in a repository or archive for permanent safekeeping according to applicable laws, regulations, or policies." 

The last sentence is fine for sites.  However, there needs to be an additional, similar sentence that all publications and public reporting should identify the repository where the collection is curated for future access and use. It could say something like: "An interest in preserving and enabling future access to archaeological collections must be taken into account by identifying the repository where the collection, whether objects and associated records or associated records only, are curated in all forms of public reporting."
column24:
This is an important principle, but it has some gaps. 

The 1st sentence should use "associated records as defined in 36 CFR 79" instead of "records".  Although those regulations are for federal collections, SAA could use that definition for all the "records" it refers to in its ethics since it is the most comprehensive definition out there.

2nd sentence: 1) add to the list of people to encourage so it says "colleagues, students,  descendant communities, teachers, advocationalists, collectors, and others"; 2) "in their research" should also include "in their research, heritage uses, and teaching"; 3) is much too long overall so should be rewritten as 2 sentences.

Also, see Childs, S. Terry (2004) Our Collective Responsibility: The Ethics and Practice of Archaeological Collections Stewardship, Society for American Archaeology Press, for the many other ethical issues that stem off of this one principle.
column26:
This only focuses on fieldwork.  It must include something on collections-based research and the training necessary to do that!

Also, the focus is on "research".  There are other things that archaeologists and their partners do that aren't just research, like heritage uses, interpretation, compliance, historic preservation advocacy...
column30: Although the SAA principles cover lots of key issues, there are many gaps that I mentioned above.  They need work and I'm sure there are a number of issues that I haven't mentioned and others will.  Our work lives are quite different from what they were in 1996, especially with the development of a lot of technology that wasn't available 25 years ago.
column36: I'm sure there are, but I am not thinking of them right now.  Hopefully you will have a long list when you are done with the survey.

column10: There is not one.  Development of professional standards for Curation of electronic records in perpetuity.  Treatment of women and minority groups especially in field and professional situations. Appropriately balancing professional voice with descendant voice. Teaching ethics.
column12: In general, folks seemed to feel that the conflict between archaeologists and descendants could be resolved, and that proper stewardship does allow for multiple uses of the archaeological record. However, the question regularly arose “as archaeologists, is our primary responsibility to the record or to the descendants or to the field of archaeology?”.  In general, it was agreed upon that archaeologists’ primary responsibility is to the archaeological record. If this means that we excavate a threatened site to collect data against the wishes of descendants, then so be it. If this means that we preserve a site for the future and don’t let archaeologists dig it today, then so be it. A minority opinion was that, as anthropologists as well as archaeologists, our primary responsibility was to the descendants.
column14:
What is meant by a “higher claim” in terms of application? Despite the above argument that archaeologists should place a priority on the archaeological record, there is a genuine recognition that other groups may have other priorities. In terms of working wiht other groups, it was agreed upon that this is a good thing but someone needs to be THE decision maker. However, there was a lot of disagreement over who THE decision maker should be. Many folks felt it should be an archaeologist, some folks felt it should be a descendant, and some of the older and wiser folks among us suggested a neutral arbitrator in which all stake holders brought their claims to the table, and then the arbitrator would make the final decision.  

In terms of public accountability -- again, no one disagrees with this idea, but how is it enforced? Who decides what is enough public accountability? What IS public accountability? If this principle was rewritten, more specific information along these lines seem warranted.
column16: Political exploitation is different than commercial exploitation, and needs to be addressed. It could be a separate principle, or this principle could be expanded. Archaeology is used by the media to support or refute modern political issues (such as laws effecting casinos or health care) as well as used to legitimize some groups and not others (such as the Navajo reservations recent requirements for archaeologists to use the derogatory term “Anasazi” in any reports written for the Navajo nation) or the popularization of Kennewick man as evidence of early Anglo occupation in the New World. Archaeological data are used to spread misinformation concerning modern political issues, and it is the responsibility of archaeologists to not allow their data to be used in such a way, or to publicly correct such misuse of their data through editorials or other public venues.
column18:
We should include as part of our statement the recognition that soldiers are a special class of the public that need to be educated, and potentially the SAA should create a special committee to work with the military. 

Archaeological projects -- whether they are using undergraduates or using public volunteers -- can be equality rigorous.  If “public education” programs are thought of and ran like a good field school, then there need not be a difference between the “rigor” of projects.  It is probably more an issue of attitude on the part of archaeologists and academics then an actual difference in project quality. 

Can public outreach projects be certified through RPA like field schools can be? Would that be an approach to creating a sense of “rigor”?
column20: This topic caused the loudest, most aggressive, and most defensive discussion even though every one seemed to agree. It is generally agreed upon that the archaeologist who did the work “owns” the data and the interpretation -- not the descendants, not the university, not the museum, not the funders. UNLESS there is some pre-agreed upon contract, documents and data belong to the archaeologist (the PI).  HOWEVER (again the older and wiser PIs among us) agree that arrangements need to be made as to the long term stewardship of such information BEFORE PIs die or retire, and that consulting with descendants prior to publication might be in order.
column22: Clarification and further elaboration would be nice, including how this integrates with Principle No 5
column24:
A lot of the discussion on this topic was tied back into previous Principles and ended up almost seeming redundant. Again, the discussion was similar to that of Principle No 1 -- our priority is to the archaeological record, and not to the descendants, and so we should preserve archaeological data regardless of potential consequences.  Also, some folks revisited Principle No 5 and intellectual property and who has the right to use and interpret the data and also stewardship of records and preservations before PIs die or retire. Despite folks’ apparent disagreement with any type of ‘censorship” of records and preservation of records, there appeared to be general agreement that access to some records may restricted to “professionals with a need to know”.  Also, there seemed to be general agreement that things like burials should maybe not be shown during a power point presentation.  

Based on how all over the discussion was, my opinion is that this Principle should probably be rewritten and clarified.
column26: No one disagreed with this principle, however it generated a lot of discussion. Is it ethical for departments to be churning out so many PhDs with emphasis on becoming an academic when academic jobs are so scarce? There appears to be a move away from MA and CRM programs, shouldn’t we be seeing more of these at universities rather than fewer?  How do we truly integrate our academic programs to train students to go into CRM and Government jobs?
column28: Finally. Would have been nice if the SAA Board and this committee actually listened to the SAA Committee on Ethics 3 years ago.  Go back and look at all the work they did - it will save time and maybe save you from losing any more SAA members.
column30: It sorely needs to be updated.  We have been saying that for many years.

column16: The principle may seem to vauge to some readers. I like that there is flexibility because it addresses the reality lived in the United States where archaeological resources from private land are generally considered private property by local, federal or state laws.
column22: I agree with the principle stated here and think this is a major problem in academic archaeology today. Many researchers are unwilling to share or publish data sets and a lot of research is based on who you know and whether or not they find favor in working with you. Some data sets never become accessible even after decades since data collection or the death of a researcher.
column28: I think this principle needs to also apply to the SAA. There  needs to be systems in place to deal with allegations of professional and sexual misconduct especially as it pertains to alleged or demonstrated offenses by members of the SAA or its employees.

column32:
I mostly agree with this statement for the US, with the exception of needing more direct language to address responsibilities to indigenous and descendant communities. 

In Mexico, where I work, major power and wealth differentials play out between Americans and Mexican Nationals. 
I would imagine the same issues are pertinent in other countries when American researchers travel, access materials and work with collaborators or paid non-academic employees.

column18: Even though I work for a federal agency I do not see the need to advertise resources available for the taking. I do promote Universities using public lands as a resource base for research. Any outreach they conduct is generally appreciated.
column20: This is truly a hopeful statement. I find most researchers say they are open to sharing information beyond what is published in a report, but I think the possibility rarely occurs. Unless the information involves a very important site, I think most researchers are focused on their own research. And if it is an important site, I think the original researcher may see "a reasonable time" as ending with their death.
column22:
I am a little bothered by the "as wide a range of interested publics as possible".  Especially if the knowledge gained deals with sensitive cultural information.

Conversely, it is a pain to find a report that only had five original copies and the nearest one is 300 miles away in the SHPO's office.
column24: I am an advocate for the review of unreported projects. I know of several field schools and small projects that, for one reason or another, were never adequately analyzed or reported. These museum collections are a perfect source for those types of studies.
column26: I encourage the principle of data recovery, but it has to be done correctly.
column28: I seen women who were very good archaeologist get out of the profession because of the 'old boy' attitudes in some companies. I've also been in offices where women were well supported and advanced rather quickly.   I have also seen young men flounder from lack of support. They all need good mentors and equal opportunities. Let their skills dictate their success. Kind of harsh, but kind of true.
column34: As a federal employee we have certain legal requirements for reporting, preservation, and equal pay and duties for the genders.
column36: This will be, I'm sure, a very touchy subject. I would like to see the code of ethics address commercial CRM firms. I know many very good commercial CRM companies, I've worked for some great ones and some so-so ones. I've heard of some, let's say, questionable ones. Maybe I'm not the person to bring this up because while I've always been taught that I was to be an advocate for the resource, my paycheck rarely has had a deadline attached to it.  other archaeologists have told me about projects where large sites were investigated with four 1X1 meter units before a pipeline went through. In my early days I was on a survey of a couple of thousand acres with 20% visibility and an average shovel test interval of 1 per acre. (Now I would sue a company that tried that.) I've been on 'surveyed' public lands and found  several, fairly large, lithic scatters. I know the ACHP only requires a good-faith effort during survey, but it seems a chunk of commercial CRM archaeologists are atheists.

column10: There are ethics involved in the practice of archaeological research. These concerns include proper treatment of cultural resources, consulting with stakeholders and governmental entities, and documenting research appropriately. I also see ethical principles in the way that people participating in archaeological research are treated. As an archaeologist, I have a responsibility to make sure that my coworkers, staff, and students are provided a safe work environment, which includes occupational health and an environment that protects people from sexual harassment, violence, and other harm.

column9: As part of my duties on the SAA Ethics Committee, I reviewed the ethics codes of the AAA, RPA, AIA, EAA and other related organizations and prepared a report for the Committee
column10: All of the issues addressed in the SAA's current code are still of great concern today. Most of these issues address archaeologists' responsibilities to other archaeologists, students, and the archaeological record. Unfortunately, the current code does not adequately address ethical issues and archaeologists' responsibilities in dealing with the public, in particular Native Americans, descendant groups, and others concerned with the archaeological record.
column12: Archaeologists are not the sole stewards and caretakers of the archaeological record, but must recognize that Native Americans and other descendant groups also have concerns and interests in the conservation and protection of that record. Archaeologists have a responsibility to work together with those groups and address their concerns
column14: This principle can be improved if we specify that "affected groups" includes Native Americans and descendant groups that may not be directly affected by archaeologists professional activities.
column18: Last sentence is always seen as a copout and should be strengthened
column22: This principle could be strengthened by being more specific about a suitable place for safekeeping; e,g.; a qualified repository
column30: Archaeologists have often developed a bad reputation with Native Americans and other descendant groups, whose ancestors created the archaeological record that we study. Archaeologists have benefited financially and intellectually from the study of this record, often at the expense of these groups, either through the loss of resources or other economic losses, or their patrimony. There needs to be a principle that specifically recognizes the interests of Native Americans and other descendant groups and the responsibility of archaeologists to give back to the members of these groups through such means as employment, training, and capacity building to empower these people to become better and more knowledgeable stewards of their own heritage. Many archaeologists have done this training indigenous people as archaeological field technicians and analysts and building local museums to support heritage tourism to aid local economies and preserve local cultures. And while I am on the subject of heritage, this might be a good place to address what cultural heritage consists of. When we talk about the archaeological record, the emphasis is on tangible heritage--the houses, pottery, and tools created in the past. But we should not ignore the intangible heritage--the customs, language, dances, and festivals associated with those material objects. It is this intangible heritage that indigenous groups are usually most interested in preserving and archaeologists must recognize the need to assist them in this respect.
column32: As stated elsewhere, I don't believe that principles adequately deal with issues affecting Native Americans, descendant groups and other affected parties. The existing principles focus on the concept of dong "no harm." But we also need to address archaeologists responsibility to do 'good". The great bulk of archaeology today is publicly funded. We not only need to make our research relevant to the public, but must also work to contribute to the public good. We cannot continue merely to address the intellectual interests of archaeologists and a small group of enthusiasts. This is not only for altruistic reasons but for archaeology's survival.

column43:
The principles have to be an aspirational code that encourages ethical behavior, there is little behavior that can be enforced. That is the role of the RPA. 

The archaeology profession has changed dramatically since its inception as has the world in which it operates. Thus, the principles that guide archaeology need to be updated and modified periodically.

An ethics forum like that used by the AAA is an excellent idea. Such a forum not only provides a platform to respond to current ethical issues, but helps individuals understand how the principles apply. Including examples from the Ethics Bowl would provide fictional examples that would avoid actual controversies and maintain anonymity..

I see two, which are not mutually exclusive

column12: I agree that we should promote protection of the archaeological record, but we need to also be sure to recognize that there are some aspects of the record not meant to share with those outside of its descendant community. The benefit in those cases is not to all people, but rather specifically to the record's community.
column14: Consultation is not consent. The phrasing in this statement offers too many "outs" for an archaeologist to not collaborate snd work with a community. No work should be conducted without the descendant community, "make a reasonable effort" is too lenient to allow an archaeologist to conduct work without community involvement. Sending an email could be reasonable effort, but that does not mean the work should continue. Ethical archaeology ALWAYS includes the descendant community.
column18: I am a huge advocate for public archaeology and wholeheartedly believe archaeologists should engage in it more often. BUT I don't think it should be required, as described above. Some archaeologists are terrible public communicators and can cause more harm than good, for both communities and archaeology. Also, we need to recognize that there is a very colonial history to public archaeology (i.e. sites being opened to tourists during the early ages of archaeology in North America) and in some cases public archaeology is inappropriate. I believe public archaeology should be conducted ethically, but not all ethical archaeology includes public archaeology.
column20: Again, despite my strong support for public access to archaeology and recognition of the problems associated with limited access, I have to point out that there are some aspects of the archaeological record which are not meant to be shared with those outside of the descendant community. Materials/documents should not be required to be shared, they should only be made available to share with community involvement.
column22: Once again, public sharing of knowledge should be encouraged but not required. If a descendant community wishes for information to stay within their community then we need to respect and honour that.
column26: This should also include that archaeologists must work to improve accessibility to the required training.

column9: I have used ethics codes for the American Anthropological Association, Archaeological Institute of America, and Register for Professional Archaeologists. I use the ethics codes for teaching courses in higher education and in my publications. I also use the codes to make decisions in my community-based heritage work.
column10: We need ethical guidelines that place greater emphasis on the responsibility of archaeologists to living people and collaborative research. The current SAA code of ethics places too much emphasis on the archaeologist as the steward of the archaeological record. This is problematic because NAGPRA has established that we, as archaeologists, must share our stewardship responsibility with a diversity of stakeholders. A greater emphasis on living people also refers to issues of harassment in the workplace and the field. We are supposed to maintain professional relationship with our colleagues but I wonder if the SAA code of ethics should contain stronger language on gender-based, race-based and other forms of harassment.
column12:
The principle places great emphasis on objects but people, other than the archaeologist, enter in as an almost afterthought in the form of an amorphous totality ("all people"). Although protecting the archaeological record for "all people" sounds like a nice idea, in practice this type of statement leads into a myriad of ethical quandaries. For example, ideas of national patrimony and world heritage are used to marginalize indigenous people in Mesoamerica and other parts of the world by providing a justification to remove people from their land. Several decades of research have demonstrated that object focused archaeologists will likely not have a bright future because indigenous and descendant communities all over the world are increasingly demanding stewardship over their heritage. Thus, I think we need a first principle that emphasizes a shared responsibility over the archaeological record and some mention of archaeologist conduct in relation to living people.

Principle 1 has a lot of merits but it makes no mention of our responsibilities to collaborate with descendant groups or to avoid harming living people.
column14: I generally agree with this statement but more of Principle should be included in Principle 1. I would also add that archaeologists should make every reasonable effort, in good faith, to AT LEAST consult actively with affected groups...
column16: I agree with this sentiment but archaeology is inherently a project of commodification. Whether we are contributing to the formation of tourism sites or publications, we are laboring with the archaeological record to create commodities. To me the real question is how we value the archaeological record, which Principle 3 somewhat discusses.

column22: I agree with this statement but I think publication should be done in consultation with descendant groups. NAGPRA has established we cannot publish whatever and however we want. column12: I agree with what I understand that motivation and sentiment of this principle to be: that archaeologists have ethical and professional obligations beyond accountability to the goals and norms of their field. But, as many have remarked, claiming to serve as stewards on behalf of others is problematic. Archaeologists have particular expertise and authority that they should use to "promote public understanding...", but they are also stakeholders for whom archaeological material is a resource. I agree that archaeological uses of the record should often take precedent over other uses (e.g., commercialization, destruction by land-owners or for political reasons), but not always, as when archaeological material  is valued as cultural heritage in ways that aren't served by archaeological investitation.
column18: I think this principle captures the expansive range of responsibilities archaeologists have to non-archaeological stakeholders, but would be better formulated if it recognized that some communities have special standing with respect to the heritage value of archaeological sites and materials; journalists, reporters, the general public are not (necessarily) on the same footing as members of an Indigenous community who count archaeological material as part of their cultural heritage.
column22: I believe this requirement of public reporting and publication should be qualified with a recognition of ways in which certain kinds of publication / publication of some types of material endangers the archaeological record and/or compromises other heritage values associated with the record.
column30: ...with the qualifications I note in response to specific principles.
column32: Indigenous communities are a strong presence in the contexts in which I work, so recognition of heritage rights and interests is especially important. See my comments on specific principles, indicating where I think they could/should be revised or qualified to recognize such situations.
column36: Rather than adding or replacing these principles I would suggest articulating a broader rationale for them - that archaeologists are responsible not just for avoiding practices that do harm to those who have a stake in and/or are affected by their work, but should also aim to work in ways that benefit them, with principles of justice an orienting goal. I believe these broader aspirations underpin many of the specifics set out in the existing principles but I think it would be worth making them explicit.

The document that sets out  standards for practice would benefit by incorporating concrete examples of what these standards require - e.g., cases of best practice and clearly problematic practice.

column10: Sexual assault and sexual harassment are big issues in the field - both literally in the field, and at conferences, in the classroom, and in our offices.  Other ethical issues of great concern right now are how US bioarchaeologists are talking about and working with NAGPRA - some are doing a really great job, while others are really not.  There is also currently no way to professionally censure an archaeologist for any ethical misdoings, allowing those archaeologists to continue to be unethical and work in new places and with new people, often without employers or colleagues any the wiser.

column10: CRM firm not allowing archaeological PIs or archaeologists to run a project properly. The hiring of unqualified field personnel by Project Managers not giving senior archaeologists a say in who is hired for the projects. The firm that is venturing from environmental to cultural believes that archaeology is in the way. Firms believe that their jobs are to save clients money not to get the client through the regulatory system properly. Firms believe that any biologist can conduct an archaeological investigation under little supervision. These firms also have no idea what it takes to conduct proper conservation of archaeological artifacts.

1. How to respectfully study the pasts of other peoples.

3. How to balance spreading enthusiasm about archaeology while protecting the archaeological record. More specifically, what do I say to a person who is excitedly telling me about the objects they collected (often from their own lands but sometimes from protected lands)?

column10: 1) Doing archaeology in ways that respect tribal interests and concerns; 2) Balancing open science with historic preservation.
column12: I think the discipline has gone overboard with the concept of preservation, with several negative consequences: 1) restrictions on the use of site location data in research; 2) active preservation that goes even beyond tribal wishes; 3) preservation for its own sake, when the reality is that the archaeological record is in a constant state of decomposition so potential information is being lost for every year a site is "preserved."
column14: But at the same time, archaeologists need to stand up for the value of what they do.
column16: But many private citizens who hold collections of antiquities take good care of them and are natural advocates for archaeology. I think there is an opportunity to take advantage of private interest in developing ethnical private curation practices. In general I find the UK's approach to this issue (esp. the Portable Antiquities Scheme)  to be much more effective than current US practice.
column20: I agree that the data, documents and knowledge of the archaeological record is not private property, but I'm not sure it is part of the archaeological record either. I think it is simply public knowledge. So, for example, site locations are specifically exempted from FOIA because of the idea that public knowledge of site locations poses a danger to them. I think experience shows that in fact that far greater danger comes from the public NOT knowing where they are, because when the public is in the dark there is no push for protection in the face of development. I also think we need to re-evaluate the assumption that government agencies actually care about preservation. Once this is acknowledged, it becomes clear that limits on public access to information generated through archaeology actually undermines preservation. A generation ago looting was a primary mechanism behind site destruction--today, I think the primary mechanism is oil and gas development on public land.
column22: As I have said, I think the assumption that public knowledge of site locations endangers their preservation needs to be re-evaluated. I am in more favor of mutual public monitoring of sites as a means of protection. When preservation is a shared value, the more people know where sites are, the better!
column24: The more information from previous work is available for additional research, the less new impact to the archaeological record from new field research is needed.
column26: If one considers CRM a preservation activity, then there is very little archaeology done today in the US that is destructive of the archaeological record, as there is very little excavation done by university-based researchers.
column30: The main issues we need to address are private stewardship of sites and collections, restrictions on site location information, and integration of tribal concerns and perspectives in archaeological practice.
column32: My responses deal primarily with the situation in the US.
column36: The range of issues is there, they just need to be updated to reflect current realities.

column10:
Indigenous and Minority Rights to their own heritage: Many archaeologists, probably most, work in contexts where they don't have total control over the way in which their excavations happen. Tribal participation and leadership in excavating prehistoric sites are still the exception, not the rule. Archaeology is a tool that is a necessary precursor to project development often, and too often the standards of CRM are not high enough. Tribal history is mangled through outdated boilerplate language, lack of time, or any number of factors. Same may go for some sites with special significance for historical minority communities, religious groups, women, and LGBT contexts. This is a structural issue of bad CRM budgets for atypical projects that may take more time and care to research and analyze. It is ethically bad, and it reduces the impact and significance of our work for these communities.

Publication: This is an old ethical issue that continues to be unaddressed. Projects frequently get dropped by the field personnnel due to priorities, change in career, loss of institutional support, whatever. We need to as a discipline ensure that at a minimum field reports are always completed. Repositories should all know which collections have been written up, to what degree, and finishing these reports should be prioritized over new fieldwork more often (i.e. in all cases unless the fieldwork is to address an imminent threat). 

SAA hostility to many of its members: This doesn't need to go in our Code, but there needs to be substantial structural change in how the SAA as an organization sees its responsibilities to the discipline and its members. This predates last year's conference debacle, but was reflected in it.  SAA is sitting on a stockpile of $8 million. We are in an international crisis. Groups like AAA are doing emergency loans and sharing the wealth. SAA is writing emails that provide their members with the option of asking for a refund for the 2020 conference, but the language was mealy and seemed designed to shame people into not requesting a refund. SAA seems to make a lot of its decisions based on what is easy and safe for the organization, not what is needed to protect people (the women at least year's conference) or make the discipline grow. Without commitment within the organization's staff and leadership, the Ethical principles overhaul is going to end up stuck in a committee that is not empowered to pass a set of ethical principles unless the staff and board support it. Given the decisionmaking by executive leadership over the last year, I do not want them making ethics-based decisions.

column26:
This is a real issue in CRM and sometimes in academic contexts where people bite off more than they can chew. Often people have expertise for some types of sites and not others. Sometimes their bosses write the proposal and make presumptions that they can direct a project. Also this is very "self assessment" oriented. Some people are very confident and other question themselves and never feel they are ready. And the former set of people are more likely to create issues when they assume they are qualified. And there is a business pressure to assume qualification.


How can we write this in a way where people are more reflective of this and interrogate themselves a bit more? Maybe provide a list of especially challenging site types that are more complex? Provide a set of questions that people should ask themselves?
column28: This should not be laws and policies focused. In most states and most countries, gender identity is not a protected class. SAA members shouldn't discriminate even if it happens to be legal and it should be a violation of the ethical code to discriminate unless there is a present and clear safety danger to having someone present at a dig (i.e. if a trans woman applied to excavate in Saudi, that's an area that is complex ethically and needs some thinking through).
column30:
The code hits most of the broad topics that I think are important, I would not advocate for removing any of the principles. However, it needs to be gone over carefully to make sure it goes far enough as I have put in comments about.

Also, the issue of enforceability and what the code means practically is something I think should be closely reviewed by the committee. Should the code have a different format where breaking some code rules leads to loss of membership and others are more aspirational or best practices? There's a difference between taking 8 years to write a report and sexually assaulting someone. Is it SAA's intention to have RPA deal with all SAA ethical issues, or are we going to establish our own qualifications for retaining SAA membership? I hope the Code comes to have more teeth and I fear it is just currently a document with little real-world implications. But perhaps the way the Code is used is just not highly visible.
column32: see other comments
column34: In government regulation, policy, and compliance this Code does not really address at all the responsibility of the CRM practitioner has for stakeholders, tribal groups, etc. That's a very tricky issue because obviously the CRM practitioner also has legal responsibilities to their client. But I think there's a minimum care that all archaeologists should provide to descendant communities. And I think we should shift the discipline so that archaeologists ensuring adequate consideration for descendants is seen as integral risk mitigation for their client and as part of best practices. SAA membership should work for changes to state laws in this regard too.

I am bigger on enforceability, and I think a living document makes enforceability somewhat unfair. There should be a small enforcible code that can only be changed by clear processes that are clearly advertised. And a different best practices document that could be living, possibly.

But I think ethics can move slower than say technical methods, and should be reflective as a function of the way ethics work. And I would prefer a blog to think/discuss ethical issues and then in turn influences best practices guidance that over time, after reflection, is occasionally updated.

column26: Frame this differently. Yes, archaeology can be "destructive", but if done properly then the information gained likely outweighs the destruction. In other words, by framing it in a negative way like "destructive" it can paint a bad image, a negative connotation that we then pass along to the public. I've given many a public lecture where later someone says, "if it's so destructive, why did you do it?" So I've begun using the term consumptive, we're consuming the archaeological record (responsibly, and in limited fashion using geophysics and remote sensing) to answer specific and targeted research questions.

column10: We need to ask why we do archaeology and why the public should support our work.  Many of us probably believe that by learning about the human past we are informing the present and preparing for the future.  However, there exists a great disconnect between the work we do as archaeologists and our engagement with the public.  One of the primary problems is the that our data and our publications are often hidden from the public behind paywalls.  If we are really to be a public good as field, we need to do everything in the open.  This is how we build the ultimate trust with the public.  It is disingenuous for to try to inform the public about the past but then hide our raw data and our main publications from them.  They should be able to check our work, as we all should be able to check each others work.  We need to be a science that includes reproducibility in our workflows.  We must as a society take a stance for open access publication of our articles/books, data, and our methods (such as source code).  This has to be a major component in our service to the public.  Please add open science to the ethics statement.
column12: Yes, but how can we advocate to be stewards of this 'irreplaceable' record when our datasets are never shared and our articles with our main conclusions are only available to a select few people behind paywalls.  This principle is so important but it needs to include that all our information should be openly available for free to everyone, 'for the benefit of all people'.
column14: Here again, how can we honestly say we are fully engaging the public and being accountable to the public when our data can not be checked by the public because it is not available and when our publications cannot be read by the public because they are not available.  This needs to explicitly indicate that we need open access publication of data and articles.
column16: This is very important, but don't we also lose context if the data from a proper excavation is never made available to everyone?  This is another instance of unknown context.
column18: At the very foundation of public engagement is the availability to the public of our publications (communicating interpretations), our data, and our methods.  If these are not openly available through open access publication to the public, then we are not being honest in our engagement with the public.
column20: This statement should explicitly mention the open access publication of everything.  The part about 'limited and reasonable time' can be removed.  Everything should just be made open as soon as possible.  Given the natural efforts these take, there is already some time built in for the initial researchers to work with the data.  No need to state it here as we should rather be encouraging the most rapid open access publication possible.  This is only about the data.  Articles and books should be made open access immediately upon official publication.
column22: How in the world can we say this: "accessible form (through publication or other means) to as wide a range of interested publics as possible" but not explicitly say 'open access'?  We cannot seriously say the first statement without saying everything needs to be freely available, we are currently not living up to this principle.
column24: This gets at the heart of the idea of open science: the reproducability of our results.  Here again this principle should explicitly state that records should be made open access so they are preserved for use by everyone into the future.
column26: To practically motivate people towards this goal, everything about our fieldwork should be fully open to everyone to check.

column30: The main change required now is to explicitly discuss the open and free sharing of all of the information we collect and create with the public.  This can only be done by supporting open science with the open access publication of all articles, data, and methods.

column10: The respectful engagement with other groups, peoples, and countries in which we conduct research. To be supportive of the initiatives by indigenous people in regards to the preservation and engagement with material culture.
column12: SAA primarily brings together scholars that are headquartered in the US or have been trained in the US. However, a significant amount of research takes place outside the US, and even that research within the country takes place in lands belonging to or associated with indigenous people. Stewardship as caregivers implies a sense of property as if we are THE people with authority to speak of how other people should engage with archaeological sites. The word has no recognition about our role as subject to other countries' laws and the decisions of indigenous communities. We SHOULD be advocates, and we should hold ourselves to a high standard. Still, we should also, as a discipline, acknowledge we have not been chosen to be the custodians of the archaeological remains and materials just because we study them. My concern is that the word "stewardship" implies an authority we lack.
column14: I agree though the phrasing seems to give us plausible deniability of our obligations by using words as "reasonable effort" and "good faith".
column16: Again, I agree but the phrasing is more a suggestion than a principle. For instance, what is "whenever possible"? And what specific stand does SAA take on research build upon non-archaeologically recovered collections?
column18: I would expand upon this notion that there are not only "many publics" but also many voices that actively want to engage in the discussion of the archaeological past. We should acknowledge that outreach and education should also be inclusive and not posit ourselves as holding the only appropriate narrative of the archaeological past. Outreach termed as collaboration would go a long way.
column20: I agree but again the statement lacks clarity by leaving the determination of "a limited and reasonable time" to the scholar.
column22: This phrase: "An interest in preserving and protecting in situ archaeological sites must be taken in to account when publishing and distributing information about their nature and location" implies that we are the ones that should be making a choice whether to disclose the location of archaeological sites. This goes directly against the laws of many other countries in which we practice archaeology. This is the same issue I see with stewardship in that we put ourselves in a position in which we are the ones called to make choices about someone else's past. In these principles, there is no acknowledgment of our obligations to existing laws and regulations in the areas in which we work.
column26: Where can we find " the foregoing principles and contemporary standards of professional practice"?
column28: Since this is the last principle, I would like to restate that there is an issue with the lack of acknowledgment of the laws, regulations, and actual steward institutions of the archaeological past in the many countries in which SAA members work. The only mention to respecting other countries' laws is in the context of safe educational and workplaces "that pertain to harassment and assault based upon sex, gender identity, sexual orientation, ethnicity, disability, national origin, religion, or marital status". There are laws pertaining to archaeological research in most countries as well.
column30: Archeology has a colonial past, SAA is embedded in a context of intellectual colonialism. A central issue of our ethic should be the recognition that we are working on other countries, on indigenous lands, and writing and building careers upon that history of other people. Until such an acknowledgment, SAA is missing an opportunity to prove that current scholars are self-critical and self-aware of the power relationships between the US and other national academies. It is particularly concerning that there is no mention of respecting and abiding by the laws of archaeological research in the countries in which we work.
column32: I teach and work in the US and I would agree the principles address many concerns by scholars in the US. As a Peruvian archaeologist conducting research in Peru, I do not feel that these principles address ethical concerns in my country or even recognize Peruvian academia as a partner.
column34: As a whole, the principles are a useful point of departure to start discussing ethical issues with students, so they are adequate from a teaching perspective. However, they are missing several points that are critical from my point of view.

An aspirational code should be fairly general and difficult to revise; a living document can be continuously updated and responsive, and serve as guideposts for when it becomes necessary to take the major step of revising the aspirational code. By separating PoE and SoP you gain significant clarity in the purpose and scope of each document. And it is always helpful to provide examples in some form.

column16:
I strongly agree with most of this statement aside from this clause: 

"Archaeologists should therefore carefully weigh the benefits to scholarship of a project against the costs of potentially enhancing the commercial value of archaeological objects."

Public education about any aspect of archaeology could be perceived as 'enhancing the commercial value of objects'. The inherent tradeoff of public education IS enhanced knowledge of the 'value' of archaeolgical objects. What type of scholarship constitutes this unknowing promotion of commodificaiton of the archaeological record is unclear.
column20:
I feel that archaeology should be more of a collective enterprise than it is. The hoarding of archaeological knowledge and data for the sake of personal and professional gain reflects a tendency within archaeology, and academia as a whole, that needs to changes. The tendency to take the archaeology meant for collective community benefit and use it for individual career gain needs to change within the whole academic community. 

This principle no longer applies to the vast majority of archaeological practice and ethical challenges today because most of American archaeology is performed in a collaborative, non-academic, non-individualistic work, and ethical environment. This principle needs to be amended.

column16: I would add that all archaeological investigations must have a public curation facility contracted before the investigation begins, that at minimum meets the Secretary of Interior standards if in the US or the standards of the country where the excavation is held. Archaeological collections should not be curated privately (in the house of the archaeologist or in the house of any donor or benefactor).
column18: Again I would add that there are many avocational groups out there who are excited about archaeology and too often they are not included because they are not professionals. It is very important not to discourage inclusion of the public especially local historians and avocationals, to our peril.
column20: Again I would add that the information shared by indigenous people and ethnic groups belongs to them. That archaeologists and historians must receive permission to use that information and attribute it accordingly.
column26: I would add that if the investigation is likely to uncover fragile materials (documents, interviews, artifacts) that conservation and curation be estimated into any funding that project is seeking. At least one member of the team should have training in the immediate conservation of materials coming out the field.

column12: While the archaeological record is irreplaceable, it is not a real thing.  It's a mental construct and rhetorical shorthand which we have developed with completely insufficient acknowledgment of taphonomic processes and the inherent gaps in the physical remains to which we're referring.
column14: Sure, consultation is great and I'm all for it.  However, there is no actual public accountability because most members of the public don't care about the esoteric things we're usually arguing.
column18: Drop the bullshit phrasing about "many publics."  The notion that academics, special interest groups,and governments represent the public is as bad as the misguided thinking that the public - by which I mean only "the general public" - cares as much as we do about archaeology.
column20: This first sentence is navel-gazing.  An honest statement to replace it would acknowledge that what is discussed here is the record of archaeology.  It is not a pure and holy thing.  It is what the researcher(s) thought to record while conducting archaeology.
column22: I again disagree with the fabrication of "publics."
column26: While I strongly agree with this principle, I would prefer the SAA invest in identifying ways of actually enforcing it. column28: Fuck this shit!  You've got to be kidding me.  SAA members shouldn't strive to avoid violating laws, they should simply not harass or assault anyone. column20: In most cases yes. Field records, notes, etc. but not a researches own thoughts regrading interpretation. Yes, the data/information collected through archaeological field work (that resulted in the removal of cultural remains from a site) should be accessible for anyone to work with. But a person's (researcher's) thoughts about a topic are their own property. The notes/paper written by someone studying an artifact housed at a museum must remain their own intellectual property. I could imagine no circumstance that that researcher be forced to make their documents of study available to others if they do not want to. This is an obvious case, but be careful with the wording in Principle 5. As it is written now, these cases would require submission since they involve the study of an archaeological resource.

column10: Some primary ethical concerns in my opinion include: Appropriate professional behavior, proper preservation of physical and digital archaeological data, proper public dissemination practices, and proper conduct with descendant and local communities
column12: Agree but would like this principle to elaborate the definition of archaeological record to include the digital information that encompasses the archaeological record and the importance of preserving the digital data. column18: I agree but would like to include as one of the efforts being making their data available and open to the public as much as possible. This will also require proper preservation, curation, and substantial metadata for others to make use or understand the data. Thus for those archaeologists unable to undertake public education and outreach, their research data about their projects are available.
column20: Expand to include that the digital data along with substantive metadata.
column22: Data should not just be presented for and in publication. It should be the responsibility of the archaeologist to have their data submitted to a a repository to ensure the long-term preservation and accessibility of their data.
column24: elaborate the list of what should be preserved to include physical and digital data. Responsible use should be expanded to include proper citation and credit of both physical and digital data (including datasets).

column10: The commercialisation of archaeological excavations.
column16: I agree but there has to be a balance between any archaeology company or government departments having a monopoly on archaeological finds. Yes they should be sold for individual profit but archaeology and what we find shouldn't be hidden or stored in boxes deep in a museum storage. And also it would depend on the artifact. For example I came across any amount of bone pins excavating in Ireland. So many people would appreciate having or seeing these for their enjoyment and given there abundance I see little harm or need to store hundreds of thousands of them in storage. This is the legislation in Ireland so everything belongs to the state from its discovery. I would be more worried about the commercialisation of the excavation process as that can cause as much damage through shortcuts and money saving tactics as the selling of artifacts.
column26: I would strongly agree, especially with facilities and support, but training on the job without experience is vital too. Some of the best archaeologists I've worked with did not study or train for archaeology but were workers brought in and trained by on site archaeologists. Also most of what I learned while studying archaeology was of little use in the field, I learned on the job as much as anything. I don't think people who have an interest in archaeology should be turned away for lack of experience or training. Archaeologists should be liberal with their knowledge of excavation with anyone no matter there background. If someone is going to illegally excavate a site at least they may follow some basic principles of excavation if that information was more readily available.

column10:
Archaeologists have serious ethical lapses. Among the most serious of these is the insistence of the archaeological community that they can and should speak for cultural resources writ large, not just the scientific or cultural interests of archaeology. 

CRM, academic, and state and federal archaeologists regularly recommend (and often say that they have determined) that no historic properties will be effected by undertakings if significant archaeological resources are not found during a survey. Even when Tribe have identified ethnographic resources or TCPs, many archaeologists insist that they have addressed Tribal concerns through archaeology, or by noting that popular collections of Indian legends don't mention their project area. Further, many CRM firms recommend archaeological monitoring during projects, even when the concern is for ethnographic landscape or other resource values important to Tribes. 

This outrageous behavior serves the business interests of archaeologists, and creates busy work to keep archaeologists employed. It does not, however, benefit the resources or tribal communities for whom they hold value, and the SAA needs to discourage their members from doing this. 

Many archaeologists also insist that working with looters is ethical, since looted collections may still have scientific value. However, this again discounts the value that ancestral sites and resources have to tribal communities.
column14: I agree, but few archaeologists understand what "consultation" means. It is not a notification letter, or asking for affected communities to observe archaeologists on a project in the field. It is a meaningful discussion where the answer to question asked of Tribal communities can be "no", and the archaeologists have a responsibility to respect and abide by that answer. To often, archaeologists rely upon state or federal agencies to engage tribes for them, or insist that they are bound by their contracts, signed before any tribal engagement occurred.
column16: Yet, some current SAA committee members actively encourage working with looters.
column18: Public education is not the primary function of the archaeological profession, and what does occur is usually focused on the majority community, rarely acknowledging the relationship of American archaeology to native communities. Archaeologists excavate ancestral Tribal villages and sites, yet  they usually don't make the effort to include Tribal peoples in studies. Archaeologists continue to want to study Indian stuff, without input or interference from actual Indians.
column20: I agree, but tribal communities must have a strong voice in what happens with the physical remains of their ancestors. Many are happy to have material stored in museum for display or future research, but others want materials returned to the earth after the study is completed. There are complex ethical issues about preservation, but also about political and economic power, the legacies of colonialism, religious and cultural values, etc. This decision cannot be left to archaeologists alone to decide.
column22: The appropriate place for safekeeping is not in a CRM office - SHPOs and museums should have all original materials, and the funding from the CRM companies to maintain them.

column9:
Absent finding anything more useful in the realm of codes of ethics, I cite county, state, and federal laws and best practices to try to convince others (including historical societies) not to publish the locations of archaeological sites online. The SAA Ethics Guide refers to this issue in Principle 6, but its a bit subtle and lost in other issues related to publication within the same principle. 

For the ethical practice of archaeology, I use the principles of Community-Based Participatory Archaeology as outlined by Sonya Atalay (2012) Briefly, it can be stated as 1) the use of a community-based, partnership process 2) that is participatory in all aspects, 3) that builds community capacity, 4) that engages in a spirit of reciprocity and 5) that recognizes the contributions of multiple knowledge systems.
column10:
This likely varies by locality, but in Southern California, where I work as an archaeologist for a government agency, I have found the work of archaeologists working in CRM firms to be woefully lacking in rigor and accountability. I have found, for example, numerous instances of archaeologists using pedestrian surveys to speak to the likelihood of sub-surface cultural resources. I have seen archaeologists more concerned about their employer's budget than they are (which is saying something) and using that as a reason to resist doing any archaeological testing (only pedestrian survey and monitoring). If they do test, many only want to use augers, even in highly sensitive archaeological sites. I see archaeologists propose collecting artifacts during surveys and testing when there is no budget for analysis, curation, or reburial. I also see CRM archaeologists routinely use boilerplate historical/ethnographic background sections more brazenly plagiarized than almost anything I experienced teaching undergrads for five years. At times, the ethnographic background sections are taken from other reports that were clearly located elsewhere in California. Some (though not all) have a very adversarial relationship with local tribal communities. In short, as the SHPO has no set standards for CRM work, the result has been a prolonged "race to the bottom" quality-wise. 

In academia, the lack of community-based participatory research is distressing. The practice of individual archaeologists and academic institutions buying land for the purposes of excavating without having to answer to the local community should be banned.
column12: This principle is more honored in the breach than the observance. Archaeologists are still far too eager to punch holes in the ground instead of investigating previously-excavated collections. Doing so is not made any easier by poor curation practices. Additionally, this principle does not recognize that archaeologists are not the only stewards of archaeological materials. Descendent communities, who have a greater claim as stakeholders of cultural resources usually have different views from archaeologists of what stewardship looks like, and their wishes should be prioritized more than others. More often than not, the "benefit of all people" hides a colonial mentality, which extracts material resources from their place of origin for the benefit of a very small public, one, if we're being honest, really just benefits the archeologists involved.  Archaeologists can easily manipulate this principle, claiming they alone know what is best for the material record and therefore are better protectors of artifacts sites than the cultures to which they belong. Even though the accountability principle recognizes that archaeological practices should recognize the wishes of the communities most impacted by their work. The ethics committee can look to the ethical principles of community-based participatory research for direction here.
column14: I feel like this principle is trying to say that archaeologists are accountable to the public, but is poorly-written and easy to misunderstand. It would be better to recognize that there are many publics, and some (such as descendent communities) should be given greater weight than others. It would also be good to recognize the imbalance of power between local communities and archaeologists (and the research institutions or developers they represent). All too often, the weight of compromise is placed squarely on the shoulders of the local community. We must account moments when communities do not want research to continue (or to start) and those wishes should be honored as much as possible by archaeologists.
column16: It would be good to mention something about the reality of economic disparities between archaeologists and local communities. Ways of promoting the local economy-- more than just the temporary hiring daily workers, but things like providing job training opportunities, tutoring school children, donating to local non-profits, providing English classes, etc.) should be thought of as a means of mitigating the destructive nature inherent in archaeology. This will help steer community members away from looking to looting as a source of income. Also, archaeologists should be encouraged to giving talks in the local language about the danger that looting represents to the community.  I don't think it happens much any more, but archaeologists have a history of buying sacred objects and objects of cultural patrimony  by applying various kinds of duress, particularly to impoverished communities. I think it would be good to acknowledge archaeologists role in creating a market for looters, so as not to place all the blame on economically disadvantaged individuals.
column18: This principle assumes that archaeologists are the sole bearers and transmitters of knowledge of culture. This principle should be called community engagement rather than outreach.  It is true that there are many publics, and that content should be tailored to the needs of those publics, but it would be good to include mention that the primary beneficiaries of community/public engagement should be the local community most closely associated with archaeologists' locus of research. "Outreach" sounds very one-directional, disengaged way of communicating information to communities. Archaeologists should be encouraged to learn from communities with an open mind,   and integrate their knowledge into the research. This does not mean that they should compromise their own scientifically-based knowledge... only the need to include traditional perspectives as an additional point of view on the subject. Better yet if they can look beyond literal interpretation of myths, etc. to see the wisdom of their perspective and incorporate those into their narrative and practice.
column20: This can be more specifically worded to include a prohibition on the long-term curation of cultural resources in archaeologists private property. We all know of instances where an archaeologist has died and their inheritors have refused to relinquish the artifacts, field notes, etc. in archaeologists' possession. It would also be good to include best practices, such as the fact that artifacts are best kept as close to where they were excavated as reasonably possible, to ensure access by descendant and local communities. This principle could be worded more strongly to say something like, short of an archaeologists' own writings on the subject, it is unethical for archaeologists to consider any part of the material record (including results of lab test, etc.) to their property. The idea of ownership of any part of the archaeological record is as unethical as any archaeologist claiming that they "own" the artifacts they've excavated.
column22:
This could be worded more strongly to protect the locational information of archaeological sites. This would be in line with state and federal guidelines. I have found this publication to be a helpful resource on the matter: Linda R. Zellmer (2017) Protected Places: A Survey of Laws on Archaeological Site and Cave Location Confidentiality and Their Potential Impact on Library Reference Policies and Services, Journal of Map & Geography Libraries, 13:2, 148-174, DOI:
10.1080/15420353.2016.1249446
IT would also be good to take into account descendent communities' interests with regards to the distribution of sensitive information, including archaeological site locations, descriptions of culturally sensitive artifacts and practices, etc.
column24:
There have been too many sites excavated without being published at all. Archaeologists should be made accountable for this before they are allowed to continue their excavations. SAA should ask to see evidence of such publications before releasing research grants for the purposes of excavation, and should encourage other granting institutions to do likewise. 

Archaeologists should justify why previously-excavated archaeological sites are insufficient to answer their research questions before punching more holes in the ground. 

There should also be best practices on how to make sure that paper records aren't removed from artifact collections. There are too many orphaned collections out there, and we need to take steps to ensure that we aren't continuing to make the same kinds of choices that lead to this issue.
column26: I struggle again here, as in other principles, by the fact that so much of the ethical burden (as it is represented) is placed on the victims of other people's neglect and selfishness. So many professors neglect to invest time in their graduate students, including with regard to their adequate training, which is usually justified by an attitude of "if you're smart, you'll figure it out." Additionally, the enormous costs of attending field school have resulted in fewer students getting sufficient opportunities to refine their field techniques. The costs of field schools also proportionately disadvantage low-income students,  perpetuating the low population of Historically Underrepresented Groups in archaeologists.  To remediate this issue, anthropology departments should be encourage students to participate in salvage excavation projects (ie, when data recovery is a must, not a whim), possibly even developing relationship with local land management agencies and CRM archaeologists to create apprenticeship programs to that end. Such experiences should be accepted as fulfilling field school undergraduate major requirements
column28: I don't like the way this principle is phrased in such a way that various types of harassment and discrimination are only unethical if there is a specific law against them. Also, there should be some means of holding perpetrators of harassment and discrimination accountable.

column10:
-Issues stemming from the colonial roots of archaeology, including, but not limited to, the various ways in which indigenous people have little control over what happens to ancestral places, objects, and people
-looting and the commercialization of the archaeological record; finding ways to productively engage collectors and others who don't necessarily see these things as a problem
-issues surrounding the curation of data and objects: both the need to responsibly curate digital material and finding ways to facilitate access to data and results while still protecting the archaeological record and maintaining some kind of peer-review system
-inequity within the discipline
-potential disconnects between how we train students (and the number of students we train) and the job market 
(edited later to add: the preservation of the archaeological record. This is so baked into my world view that I didn't initially think of it, but given current federal policy, yes this is a very active concern.)

column24: I wholeheartedly agree with the principal, but the wording is a little weird (specifically that "to this end"). While continued research is the justification for curation of collections, we don't work with collections *in order* to justify the curation of collections. We work with collections because of the immense research potential in them and to minimize further damage to the archaeological record. And because of this we must be committed to responsible curation. Also, why is this phrased solely as encouraging other people to work with collections?

column9:
I am a retired Air Force Officer who is a THPO for my tribe. Air Force members are well versed in ethics across many fields and subjects. In addition to my profession, I am bound by my Native American ethics, which actually are strong than those of archaeologist. I say this with authority because we do have a need to collect artifacts and we have a stronger tie to land that allows us to see the entire area as a cultural resource versus the all too often statement "...no cultural resources noted."

I pride myself on the fact that I can go on a site survey and see more than any other archaeologist can see - it goes beyond ethics.
column10:
The primary concern is that archaeologist quickly state "no cultural resources noted" which it is not too.

Consider this:
Can you know someone upon a first meeting? Can you really know someone if you visited them twice in a year or does it get time to know a person?

Lesson:
An area that is survey will look different from year to year and season to season - some plants only bloom every few years or maybe every ten years, it is difficult even for me to comment on an area when it is being surveyed for development, but it is necessary to consider vegetation, history, visual landscapes and the overall holistic approach.

Secondly is the need to collect artifacts - it needs to stop. I have worked with the Public Lands Commission in California and requested that if artifacts need to be moved that California Transportation (CalTrans) allow the Native American community determine how, when and where to put them during a 4 lane highway extension.

Curation and study are not going to restore our heritage - curation creates a money and staffing problem for several agencies - why not allow Natives decided what happens to artifacts?
column12:
I disagree with older archaeologist all the time about their theories and ideas - how is it that they are the ones that decided what is important and what gets recorded?

I learned about "lumpers" and "splitters" just a few years ago... true stewardship would revolve around understanding how communities or sites work together and support a bigger picture rather than quickly recording sites and moving on - missing something bigger
column14: Most of the Native American community that I know (its pretty big) has to push to be involved, even with 106 in place, and yet few still listen to us about our stories, ideas and knowledge
column16: Nothing should be collected anymore! The LAW still allows this and it needs to change because the archaeologist at least in the Owens Valley, California claim they have to collect and curate because of the LAW - then change it!
column18: I am working with some really great archaeologist in the Owens Valley community as well - those that are helpful reach out via phone calls and email and have regular meetings.
column20:
Many Native Americans have shared stories, ideas and knowledge - the only way that their information should be share is with personal permission or that of their families and they should receive royalties and proper acknowledgement otherwise is theft and should be publishable.

It is because this has happened in our community that elders and even myself are reluctant to share because someone will alter the information, use it to get ahead or somehow profit from the information.
column22:
All information needs to be safeguarded. In the Ownes Valley we still have "pot hunters" and "treasure hunters" that still seek graves and seek to destroy valuable sites.

I safeguard information from my tribe and only disclose what needs to be discussed for projects and to facilitate consultation at the general council level.
column24:
Same, all information needs to be safeguarded and people seeking information or to even build on previous studies needs to be vetted prior to having access to information.

Our THPO's in the Owens Valley have a concern with people who are pursuing their PHD's or Masters Degree because they build on the work of others or think they are discovering something new - many people get a lot of stuff wrong at our expense
column26:
Yes, they need tribal monitors with them who will give them advice on what to stay away from or how treat a particular site.

In our valley we have too many examples of how this goes wrong. During Data Recovery for the 395 Highway Expansion Project I asked for cadaver dogs to be used. The report came back and there is strong evidence that several areas have graves and are consistent with other indicators.
column28:
I don't know enough about this to comment. I can say that at Nellis AFB, Nevada our Consolidated Groups and Tribes and Organizations (CGTO) consisting of 17 tribes from California, Nevada and Arizona meet twice a year with Air Force Officials.

At that meeting we do hold different types of training and educational class and the Nellis AFB has set up 106 Consultation training and NAGPRA training.
column30:
In my own opinion … NO, but that is based on what I have seen and know of the people that I work with.

I "FEEL" that the principles and ethics needs to change to align with true preservation of Native American culture.

I have worked with several professionals who do a very good job and their heart is in the right place and they are willing to learn our perspective and respect us - which is greatly appreciated.
column32:
Only based on again on the notion that collection seems important and too many people still want to write their version of what they think happened historically to explain what is found.

Example:
One archaeologist insisted that an arrowhead could have only been used during a certain time period - very finite

I simply pointed out to him that Muscle Cars from the 1960 are still in great shape and can driven just the same in 2018 as they were driven in 1960 - just because its over 60's years old doesn't mean that it can't be used today.

More specifically - If I am a Native and didn't have an arrowhead and needed one, there's a good chance I would have used it to meet my needs - I may have not known or even cared if it was 200 years old.
column36:
Again, STOP COLLECTING! - Work to change these laws and allow Natives to decide

Stop making stuff up - talk with tribes and get their input - sometimes we know the answer but we are not going to share

DO NOT publish anything without getting permission and give credit when and where its due - just ask your community how it feels when someone publishes information that isn't theirs - plagerism and stealing - yeah - it's illegal.
