column10: Publication of and access to data continues to be a challenge in our field. As our science is inherently destructive, it is critical that we share the archaeological information we have collected, analyzed, and interpreted with the broader archaeological community. Timely peer-reviewed publication of data and research results is important for many reasons, not the least of which are the ability to conduct more comprehensive data comparisons across larger scales and to develop new research questions and lines of scientific inquiry that may otherwise go unaddressed. We owe it to the resource (the site, feature, historic building, artifact assemblage, etc.) to publish our results and make our data as widely available as possible while maintaining and ensuring the resource's protection in perpetuity.
column18: It might be worth considering changing "Native Americans" to "indigenous communities" or something along those lines to use more inclusive language.

column22: I think this language could be updated to include the publication and distribution of archaeological information in a digital medium which is much more widely available today than when this principle was originally written. column36:
1. Principle 6 states that "An interest in preserving and protecting in situ archaeological sites must be taken in to account when publishing and distributing information about their nature and location." We sorely need more specific guidance about this, particularly how to publish results without placing sites at greater risk to looting.

2. the SAA guidelines do not address issues of academic/scientific honesty. There is a growing problem of fabricating or embellishing results for the sake of publication or notoriety. There is also a problem of honesty when it comes to academic cv's. Most other professional societies address these issues, and SAA's should do the same.

column18: This is why I brought up those unwilling to accept alternate interpretations of their work. Often archaeological interpretations can be upsetting to descendant groups, and can encourage forms of oppression (e.g. "this culture was violent" can encourage or justify oppression because a government could claim they are protecting the people from a violent culture. So when other interpretations become available to help descendant groups make sense of their past, it is important that emerging archaeologists can publish those data and educate about new interpretations without fearing that their career will be ruined by older archaeologists who they are contradicting.

Do you think everyone pores over The Archaeology Record or committee reports to follow every argument over practices?  Why can't these statements be straightforward with examples of poor practices, or categories of practices instead of coded?
column30: Generally agree - please respond to the issues raised in comments.  This code is written by people who assume everyone shares their lingo, code words and phrases, and understanding of 'big issues'.    Basically, it as if the Hippocratic Oath said 'first do no harm' and stopped, instead of given many firm examples of behaviors that are not acceptable or are best practices. Even the Iron Age Greeks got this point.  That oath is not overly long or ponderous, please fix the just awful vague language that basically allows many bad behaviors by being so broad as to be meaningless.  It seems like an output created by some committee where no one could agree, and thus produced suggestions that could literally mean almost anything in most (not all) sections. This gives it a feeling of complete insincerity in many spots.  Like, go through the motions, then do what you need to.

column43:
Principles and practice should NOT be separate conceptually, though they may usefully exist as separate documents; all standards should be framed in terms of principles, and standards may usefully include examples

I support a stable code of ethics, but accompanied by a living document that enables archaeologists to discuss, debate, and sort out ethical challenges; the code should then be reviewed and updated on a regular basis--perhaps every 10 years, with the option to update/ review within that 10 year framework if necessary.

column10: Open science: inclusiveness, reproducibility, and accessibility of research results to the general public.
column20: There needs to be a serious conversation in the discipline about the degree to which, in contemporary archaeology, concerns over public access to the data by bad actors for "inappropriate" purposes (concerns which are often abstract, theoretical, and unsupported by any particular evidence) are used as a justification for locking down publicly-funded research data that may otherwise be part of the open commons. Does all this hoarding and hiding of data from bad actors actually work? Are the negative consequences of it worse than the consequences or just releasing it all? No-one knows the answer to any of these questions, so the default position is just to lock everything down. This needs to change. There needs to be studies done of every stage of this line of reasoning, with a view to making evidence-based, case-by-case determinations of what should and should not be released -- and perhaps defaulting to open access unless a danger to heritage can be proven (rather than defaulting to the opposite assumption as we currently do )
column22: See my answer to previous question.
column36: A recognition of the profoundly negative consequences that can and do arise from the withholding of cultural heritage data from free and open public access, in addition to the default recognition that there may be some harm, in some instances, caused by the release, and advising people to think carefully about weighing the two rather than defaulting to (usually ineffective) means of obscuring and hiding data and all the rest.

column10:
* scientific ethics - responsible collection and curation of archaeological data, relationships and interactions with host, source, and descendant communities, relationships with other stakeholders, ethics of destructive analysis

* archival ethics - who has access to collections and data once archived, are researchers from host, descendant, or source communities unfairly excluded access due to distance or financial concerns? I'd also include issues around repatriation here

* interpersonal, professional ethics - sexual harassment, intimidation, bullying 

* intersection and interrelationship between academic and professional study and looting and illegal antiquities trade
column20:
I think in many ways, this ethical principle is the one that is least integrated with the understood norms of archaeological practice. I think most archaeologists operate under the assumption that "data feudalism" is the law of the land and that data can, and needs to be, hoarded.

I think this is part of a larger conversation about what kinds of intellectual work is recognized and valued (i.e. addressing why people feel the need to hoard data). I think there is also a larger conversation about what it takes to make archaeological data, and archaeological materials, truly and widely accessible.
column28: The principle is adequate but it needs to be supported and enacted in institutional practice. Otherwise it is completely inadequate.
column30: I think the consensus nature of the principles side steps some of the thornier issues in the ethics of archaeological practice. I think the biggest "absent element" is some sort of acknowledgement of the power issues inherent in standing as gate keepers for scientific knowledge about the past. That position is not neutral, but it is also necessary in some ways. But I think archaeologists need to acknowledge the power that they have as legitimate scholars (even if it isn't as much power as we would like) and the need (and the ethical difficulty) of using that power legitimately and wisely. As an "American" organization, ideally the SAA could also undertake some deep thinking about the power imbalances between researchers from the global north and researchers and stakeholder communities from the global south -- not to mention classed and racialized communities within the global north.
column32: See my previous comment, but I think there is more to be said about the power imbalances between archaeologists and other stakeholders.

column10:
The field's relationship to Native Americans and other descendant communities. We still have a long way to go in this regard and I would like to see indigenous rights at the forefront of a revised code of ethics. 

Bioarchaeological research presents a multitude of ethical concerns. The SAA should take a stance against studies such as Ancient DNA, skeletal isotopes, etc. which are conducted on human remains without the consent of and collaboration with relevant living communities. NAGPRA protects many Native American remains in the United States, but many more fall outside its purview. The potential legality of many such studies does not make them ethically sound. Furthermore, in much of Latin America and many other areas of the world, no such protections exist. In these cases, the code of ethics may be the only guidelines influencing these studies. Therefore it is important for the code of ethics to have strong guidance in this regard. 

Another ethical concern is challenging the myth of archaeological stewardship as a justification unto itself for archaeological research. Stewardship as a concept needs to be interrogated. I do not believe that this should be given primacy in our code of ethics. 

I think it should be stressed as an ethical imperative that we address the difficult social and political history of archaeology, especially its colonial origins and continued ties to colonial and capitalist practice when teaching archaeology to various publics and training new archaeologists.
column12: The phrasing of this statement implicitly creates a hierarchy where archaeological knowledge is at the top. Archaeologists often deal with other peoples' cultural heritage, and in these instances we should not be given the singular distinction of what happens to those cultural resources. It is grandiose to position ourselves as "stewards" of the archaeological record, when there are many, many communities with a vested interest in that record. Our "specialized knowledge" does not give us any inherent rights, though our chosen titles do come with responsibilities. We should be focused on practicing an archaeological which is socially and ethically sustainable. Also, we must question and address how conservation of the archaeological record is for the "benefit of all people," when many would argue that our discipline has caused them harm.
column14: This principle is too vague. In order for it to be more impactful, it needs to be expanded upon.
column18: As these principles are aspirational, we should mention that public education and outreach should be collaborative wherever possible.
column20: The code should do more to protect the intellectual property of graduate students whose projects and ideas have frequently been co-opted by more established researchers in the field.
column24: I think digitization should be mentioned here. Digitization of records is the only realistic way to make them open-source. We should be concerned with increasing accessibility to so-called "gray literature."
column28: We need to use stronger language and take a stronger stance. This is an "aspirational" code of ethics and there is no justification for defaulting to the policies surrounding sexual harassment at various institutions. We should include our own policy against sexual harassment in this principle.
column36: I think we should do much more to address indigenous rights, including indigenous intellectual property rights, data sovereignty, indigenous ownership of cultural heritage, representation and collaboration, etc. The WAC first code of ethics far exceeds the SAA Principles in this regard, and these should serve as inspiration for additional SAA principles.

column10: Sexual discrimination. Inequities in pay based on gender. Illegal antiquities trafficking and unethical but legal destruction of sites and trade of artifacts in the USA.
column14: Sometimes archaeologists have additional obligations such as to a foreign government from whom they obtain permits for field research that govern what they can and cannot do. Sometimes public outreach must go through the government. Sometimes the government has views that cannot be contradicted if you want to get a permit. For example in Belize, the government archaeology department sides with the government who view the Maya as recent entrants to the country from adjacent countries,  whereas archaeologists have found continuous settlement from prehistoric times. Secondly, university faculty who want to earn tenure need to follow tenure guidelines for publishing etc and may not be able to focus as much time/effort as they might like, IN ORDER TO KEEP THEIR JOBS AND EARN TENURE.

column10:
Open access.

The past does not belong to the Society for American Archaeology.  It belongs to the native people whose history we study. Other stakeholders include granting agencies and the public who pays for archaeological research through taxes.

The time of hiding our results behind a paywall is over.  If we want to promote and protect the past, access to the journals must be provided at no additional cost to those who wish it.
column12:
Stewardship also includes sharing knowledge.  It is not merely the objects, sites, collections, records, and reports of the past.  We must include knowledge *about* that past in our definition of stewardship.  

That knowledge must be shared.  It is shameful that it is used to by the society and its publishing partner as a tool to make money.

The journals must be available free of charge to native peoples, tax payers, students, archaeologists around the world, and other stakeholders.  Only then will be live up to the charge of "promoting public understanding and support for the long-term preservation of the archaeological record."
column14: Missing here, once again, is the basic point that knowledge about the past, as published in our journals, must be available to all.
column16: The SAA *does* sell objects of the past.  The SAA sells objects of knowledge through the journals.  To me, these are much more valuable commodity than pot sherds and stone points.  We need to understand that there is no difference between material objects and objects of knowledge.  Both need to be curated in public and be readily available for  scientific study (including by students and scholars who currently have no access to the journals), public interoperation, and display.
column18: This is hypocritical because we hide our results behind the paywalls of AAQ, LAQ, and AAP.  These are the primary and flagship organs of public education and outreach of the SAA.  Yet we do not make them available to native people, scholars in other countries where subscriptions are rare, or the stakeholders in the USA and Canada who pay for our research with their taxes.
column20: I agree.  But the SAA does *not* hold to this as an organization!  The journals are not made available to others for free. We are hypocritical stewards of the past because we seek to profit from the knowledge and documents created through the study of archaeological resources.
column22: Yet the SAAs do *not* do this.  Instead, we hide results and knowledge behind a paywall and attempt to profit from it. How is selling knowledge of the past any different from selling artifacts of the past?
column24: This should include free access to publications about the past.
column32:
There is not a single subscription to an SAA journal in the country where I work, including private and public universities.  Yet there are approximately 200 SAA members working in that country.

How is this situation ethical?  How is it not exploitative colonialism?
column34: What is "sector"?
column36:
It is time for the SAA to take a very public and strong stance on open access to knowledge about the past.  We should promote protection of the past by placing knowledge gained from it directly in the hands of all the stake holders:  native peoples, students and scholars who have no access to the journals, the interested public, and the tax payers who support our research through public granting agencies and public institutions.

The journals should not be yet another way the past is sold.  They should be available to all who need them, not just a select few who can afford to pay for a membership or who have access to an institutional library that subscribes to the Cambridge journals.

Some might argue that this falls under the purview of museums or NAGPRA, but both of those are limited in terms of what they can do, and archaeologists should take more responsibility for the removal of cultural material from where it belongs (even if that removal happened generations ago). Maybe this falls under one of the principals already discussed, but it needs to be more clear in that case.

column28:
So, I have some real problems with this part. Before 2016, I thought this was about physical safety because I had seen so many team leaders ignore good practice about weather, water, safe working with tools, adequate food and housing, reasonable ladders, accommodating the smaller bodies of women archaeologists when providing equipment, being willing to abide by OSHA guidelines for standing walls in excavations, vehicle safety, parasitic diseases transmitted or exacerbated by excavation. etc. That kind of stuff, that is intrinsic to doing archaeology, and the things that have killed archaeologists over the generations. 
Now, it seems like "safety" is a code word for avoiding sexual violence and racism. Aspects of sexual violence protections are protected by law, as are racial hate crimes. Universities have broad mandates to enforce Title IX even away from the U.S. as a matter of protecting students involved in educational activities. I have thought a lot about this and feel like treating this as sexual violence only means that it ignores power differentials of several types that are intrinsic to education, to scientific research, and to work life generally. When a person is harassed or assaulted in the field or in a hotel by someone strong enough to overcome them, or armed, perhaps, it's bad but not all this behavior is illegal. When this is supervisor-worker setting, or a mentor-student setting, etc. it is a violation of other ethical standards involving the abuse of institutional or economic power and a crime. I know that this abuse was a root cause of the exclusion of women from the field for decades. Now that women dominate numerically in the field, I see that abusing economic or institutional power without necessarily involving sexual violence may be an even more profound issue, and one that I resist being labeled under "safety". 
.

column10: Preservation/interpretation vs. excavation (e.g. as part of mitigation). Repatriation of native/aboriginal remains. column12: The archaeological record pertains to more than just artifacts, sites, and documents. It also includes landscapes, contexts, and the collectively-held sum of knowledge (much of which is distributed digitally across the internet). Current ethical standards should incorporate language that expresses a concern for the preservation of less tangible aspects of the archaeological record - such as might be expressed by the NRHP conditions for integrity: location, setting, design, materials, workmanship, feeling, and association.
column14: I feel that this statement is intended to be vague, so as to cover many different kinds of scenarios. However, in doing so it presupposes that the archaeologist is doing the consulting. When, in fact, the law is structured such that archaeologists often can only facilitate consultation between federal and tribal representatives, not actually consult. I think the statement should be changed from "... consult actively ..." to "... consult, or facilitate consultation, actively ..." Also, the goal is not always to establish a "working relationship" but to establish an outcome, or outcomes, that are beneficial to the group(s) whose heritage is represented by the resource.
column22: The last part of the statement should be made more inclusive of the protection of sacred images, materials, and information important to the group(s) or communities who may hold an interest in archaeological knowledge. It is not just sites that need protection. But the presentation or reproduction of images of the dead, or sacred objects, etc., should not be published or released to the public without consent.
column30: Some additional specifics should be added, especially with respect to our changing understanding of what constitutes heritage and archaeology. The ubiquity of internet-based research and outcomes makes it imperative that we expand our ethical definitions to be inclusive of, or specifically emphasize, digital products or collections. Additionally, the ever-evolving nature of tribal/aboriginal consultation means our ethical standards should specifically look towards acknowledging and protecting their heritage and encouraging greater diversity and inclusiveness in the discipline as a whole.

column34: Very few archaeologists understand the ethical principles - they do not even read them, but reading them is not enough. You are not ethical because you are "nice" and "know right from wrong."

column28: This appears out of place with respect to the specific ethical issues of archaeology in the preceding 8 principles. This principle is more generic, and essentially states that archaeologists should follow general public laws (in this case, focused on disability or discrimination). These laws apply to all, not just archaeologists, and no case has been made that narrows this to a single profession. As such, adding it to a general principles list is like adding one that states "archaeologists should not murder." This is already a given. Also troubling is the current presence of two frameworks in the U.S., one a legal framework with due process rights and the other (TItle IX) which is extra-judicial with limited or no due process rights, application of this principle is muddied.

column10:
The problem of racial and gender discrimination in the discipline and the organizaitons that employ archaeologists.

The problem of the protection of archaeological sites from damage or destruction.

The problem of making sure to respect the rights of Native Americans and other indigenous people to sites and objects from sites.

The need to protect and preserve unpublished documentary, digital, and object materials from archaeological investigations for future research.
column12: I'm not sure what the next few questions will contain, but I wanted to mention here the need for a statement about how the institutions and businesses that employ archaeologists and the agencies that fund their field research also need to take responsibility for the preservation of the collections that came out of the research.  I've worked for or collaborated with a number of institutions that refused to take responsibility for the curation of the collections from my research.  As a result, I, personally, am storing important research collections in my basement, a place that is not adequate in terms of conservation either of documents (labels) or objects.  Even some of the countries I've done research in have refused to curate collections sometimes, and when they have received them the treatment they accorded the collections led to their damager or destruction.  In one case, careless smoking by local staff in a country led to a fire that destroyed collections and in another inadequate curation of a collection maintained on the site in a country resulted in all paper (labels, containers) being easten by termites.
column14: I also think that the results of archaeological work need to be disseminated by ourselves as widely as possible in order to inform and make available our material to persons or groups who can benefit from the information.  An example that comes to mind is a situation in a country where I was doing research, where local indigenous groups were being told that they had no history or heritage in the area, which at the time was being despoiled and indigenous people displaced by an organization that had falsified its application for an access permit. But the wrong information that purported to say that the indigenous people had no historic connection or rights to be there and be involved in governance was being promoted by the government of the country.  We researchers were able to show the local indigenous group slides of the archaeology and ethnihistory of the area that documented the strong evidence that the local group had been there for thousands of years and that the majority population of the country had only been there a few hundred years at most.  The lack of basic education on the history and archaeology of the area limited people's recognition of their rights and that limited their role in the preservation of the landscape of of their culture and population.
column16: But, I feel that information should always be preserved and dissseminated, even when that requires study of material that has been improperly removed from its site of origin.  In my experience, gaining the maximum information possible by that engagement has make possible mitigations and prevention of future such removals. So, I would not be favorable to any precept that would caution archaeologists to eschew the gathering of information about objects from the illegal or improper trade in archaeological materials.
column18: I feel that something should be added to this wording to emphasize that archaeologists should not criticize other archaeologists for popularizing archaeological information. There's a history of sneering at those who choose to write popular accounts, as if those are less worthy academically.  But if it's a priority to disseminate our information as broadly as possible, then we should be promoting the popularization of it.  If the statement on ethics were to say outright that this is a kind of dissemination that should be privileged because it contributes to the furtherance of our priorities I think it might discourage the dismissal of popularizers.
column20: Usually, in my experience, the countries where archaeologists work require archaeologists to file reports and records promptly with some relevant organization, such as a partrimony agency.  Then, anyone can ask to see those records.  However, I occasionally have run into a situation where a repository feels obliged to refuse to post publicly materials that a researcher has donated because of some feeling that access should be limited to individual researchers.  The Center for Research Libraries has refused to post publicly transcriptions of a particular researcher's transcripts and translations of records of accounts of an indigenous society, even though the researcher is now dead. The records are extremely important in establishing the existence of highly organized heterarchical societies before colonization, a finding that would very much benefit the descendants of those societies who are dealing with inaccurate and possibly disingenuous information from some groups of western researchers.  It would be good to include something about the need for repositories to make indigenous materials as publicy available as possible when there is no compleling reason why they should be restricted.
column22: I feel that it is often difficult to get publishers to agree to publish results in ways that allow the inclusion of specific factual evidence, such as stratigraphic profiles, pottery sherd pictures and profiles, or narratives of excavation results.  Archaeologists can certainly post their unpublished reports or file them in archives but I feel that there should be some other arrangement that could provide for the publication of such unglamorous materials in ways that would be relatively lasting.  Since publishing is now much cheaper and easier with digital methods, perhaps the policy should mention that the institutions involved in sponsoring the research or curating the collections should take responsibility for making printed and pictorial results available publicly in lasting forms.
column24: I feel that there is a problem in the way researchers handle skeletal and botanical collections that leads to the loss of information and deterioration of the specimens.  I have seen archaeologists directly handle, break in order to see the interiod of something, and neglect to replace material in its labeled container with the result that the provenience is lost and the integrity of the specimens is harmed. So, in this part of the policy there should be a statement added that archaeologists and other researchers such as physical anthropologists and botanists who study archaeological collections need to adhere to handling methods that conform to good conservation principles and expressly avoid doing harm to the material that would limit the effectiveness of its curation and make it less useful for future research.
column26: I think that the SAA should try to assist archaeologists or researchers in related fields to get good advice on how to properly and adequately handle data sampling and handling of material.
column28: I recognize that the problematic situations that were allowed to exist in the 1970s and 1980s may be less common nowadays, but perhaps the statement in the policy should be more specific.  It still seems to be the case that not a few researchers look at field work as a way to express yourself or find yourself romantically or sexually, and both students and local people in fieldwork situations stand in a subaltern relationship with foreign scientists, especially men but not only men.  It is still common for a researcher to form a relationship with a subaltern person that is by definition unequal.  These relationships often end with the end of the field season but even when they do not, the relationships often break up when the student of local person has difficulty adapting to life in the sphere of the researcher.  In any case, people who make these relationships often do not look at the social stratification aspect and don't consider what their effect is on the other person.  Something in the policy that acknowledges social inequality and the needd to protect "inferiors" from harm in unequal relationships might be good.
column30: I've marked neutral in all my responses in order to suggest that the policy could be more specific and more congnizant of the situations of possible harm to people, information, objects, and sites of researchers and institutions actions or non-actions.

column10:
Tough question, as I believe we have internal professional ethical concerns and out-ward facing "beyond the profession" concerns. The SAA Principles (in the 1990s) were mostly about internal issues before, but now have been incorporating/thinking about effect beyond the profession.

I think we need nuanced balance. These are complicated issues and the one thing in teaching them is that students tend to knee-jerk into right/wrong answers. When it comes to SOME of the SAA Principles, I think we need to discuss why we have these in place, but then also give room for debate, re-interpretation, and evolution over time. I know that is what the task force is taking into consideration.  I strongly support the addition of the workplace ethics statements, which is relatively new, and support more language on sexual harassment and assault. However, these are importantly issues that go well beyond archaeology as a profession. These are societal changes we need to make in general, not just as archaeologists.

column10: Lack of gender diversity in professional leadership positions; insufficient training for college students in historic preservation law and practices; college professors who denigrate (either implicitly or explicitly) cultural resource management work; some archaeologists tend to excavate in situations where appropriate scientific assessment could accomplished with in-field study and no excavation;  similarly, sometimes too much excavation occurs when much less could yield adequate results; large-scale excavations of preserved sites (e.g., Archaeological Conservancy properties) using field school students, volunteers, et al.;  insufficient use of museum collections for student research and research by professionals;  not reporting the results of university and college archaeological field school projects (even if only preliminary description of methods and findings).
column12: Not all archaeologists view site preservation and site stewardship as important roles of their work life, but they should.  The principles of site stewardship should begin in college, and they should be presented prominently at conferences, too.
column20: A researcher should be able to privately maintain the results of their research until such time as they are ready to present those data at a conferences, public meeting, or publication.
column24: More study of existing collections is needed.  And, museums should make their collections open for study by professionals; currently, some museums do not.  I think the SAA should investigate or at least assist in this problem area.
column26: More training on non-destructive techniques is needed.  College students should be trained in fieldwork techniques that provide adequate analysis but do not necessarily result in full-scale excavation.  For example, studies of sites and their contents can be performed in the field, onsite.  Training in taking a more holistic view of site environments is needed, such as a cultural landscape approach.  I recommend more training for students and current professionals in techniques of oral history.  College archaeology students should take courses in local history, geology, ecology, botany, etc.

column10: The politics of heritage, especially in colonial and postcolonial contexts, collaborative research with descendent communities, and the relationship between multiple ways of knowing and claiming the past and it's remains.
column12:
I think this principle is important in that it foregrounds the risk of losing irreplaceable contextual information. However, the framing of archaeologists as "stewards" is a little narrow and potentially self-serving. I think it is more important to consider how different peoples approach the archaeological record. Indigenous peoples may think of themselves as "caretakers," which is far more robust than "stewards" - my point isn't that archaeologists should be caretakers, too, but that as professionals we need to think of the complex social dynamics and interests at play. 

Likewise, is preserving heritage essential in every cultural context, or does it reflect a specific cultural framework with specific metaphysical anxieties about oblivion? Should statues of confederate generals be preserved, and what kinds of social spaces get opened up as these "heritage" objects and monuments to white supremacy are taken down?

Historically in the US, "stewardship" has meant the appropriation of ancestral Native American bodies and material culture in colonial institutions, so I think this principle needs to be reevaluated and rewritten.
column14: I think this is an important principle, although it could be stronger. The language of "affected group(s)" is also a bit vague. Is everyone equally important in these considerations, and should they be? For example, if we're talking about a space that is contested between a Native American nation and an oil company, should archaeologists be concerned with "establishing a working relationship that can be beneficial to all parties involved?" That's an extreme example, and maybe a bit black and white, but I hope it clarifies my meaning.
column16: Again, this is an important issue. However, I am a little concerned by the way it assumes archaeologists are the proper owners of "cultural resources" or "the archaeological record" - I work in North America, so the history here is of settlers claiming ancestral Native American bodies and material culture.
column18:
This is an extremely important principle to me. However, the framing favors a unilateral model of outreach as opposed to collaboration, in which archaeologists communicate expert knowledge to a lay public. A truly cooperative effort would go beyond this. I think that any archaeologist who works with descendant peoples will tell you, we learn far more rich and powerful information from community members than we can ever really reciprocate. Particularly important to consider here are how archaeologists should engage with multiple ways of knowing, including oral traditions. 

Likewise, should archaeologists seek to enlist the support of Indigenous publics (for example) for the stewardship of the archaeological record, or should non-native archaeologists learn from Indigenous caretaking practices?
column20:
I think this should be made stronger. Maybe I'm wrong, but basically I read this as saying that researchers can maintain primary access to their materials for a while, so they can receive due credit through publications, but the ultimate goal is eventual open access. This is worth stating explicitly, and ties back to the previous principle about public education and accessible information. Some universities offer funds to publish open access - maybe its worth calling for this to become more widespread and better funded? On the other hand, there are a number of complexities here - I know I certainly don't have the knowledge to create a public database of my materials.

However, not all information is appropriate for open access. Again, my expertise is in Indigenous contexts, where some information is not appropriate for certain outsiders or social groups. I know sociolinguistics have developed databases for public projects in which users have limited access to materials on the basis of things like clan and gender.
column22: I have the same question as my earlier statement that not all information is appropriate for all audiences. However, is a potentially underfunded archive or even the attics of community leaders a "suitable place for permanent safekeeping"? I think that if there is a descendant community interested in claiming the materials, they should have the primary claim - although I understand that would be an extremely complex determination in many cases). But the alternative is reproducing colonial relations in which Indigenous materials are unilaterally claimed as national heritage. Of course, many tribes have excellent museums and preservation capacities, and many might prefer objects to be kept in a university or museum with those capacities, but I think these are issues that the SAA needs to tackle head on.
column24: This is an important value. However, it is again a bit universalizing - while naturalizing archaeologists as the sole proprietor of cultural resources.
column26: I think this is essential. I would encourage the Task Force to take it further and state that archaeologists should receive training in research with descendant communities.
column28: I thing the segment on harassment should be made stronger, or even given its own principle in addition to the language in here. Framing this in terms of following laws is a bit of a disservice, I think - particularly when law enforcement is notoriously bad at enforcing these laws, particularly in communities of color. Anyway, harassment is unethical, regardless of existing laws, and "passing the buck" in this way is a bit of a punt in my opinion.
column30:
I think the existing Principles are good within a very narrow scope - of outlining a fairly self-serving vision of preserving the archaeological record for archaeologists. I don't mean that those considerations aren't important, just that they're narrow.

I think there needs to be more attention to community-based archaeology and archaeology that works with descendent communities. In that vein, I think more attention needs to be given to the specifically colonial and postcolonial political contexts that archaeology is conducted within. Trying to frame ethics in more neutral terms that leaves these power relations unnamed only re-inscribes normatively colonial and settler vantage points. As it stands, the Principles of Ethics normalizes archaeologists as the natural proprietors of the archaeological record - a state of affairs solidified in the 1906 American Antiquities Act as it classified Indigenous remains as national heritage - in a way that obscures the more complex and contested politics of who owns the past.

Likewise, I think the segment on harassment - and discrimination - needs to be expanded. In particular, the ongoing structural racism, colonialism, sexism, and classism in academic universities, as well as micro-aggressions, should be discussed explicitly. In this sense, I would take the review of the Principles of Ethics as an opportunity to frame a system of ethics for creating a discipline and practice of archaeology that better serves marginalized and historically underrepresented communities. For example, archaeology is not an especially diverse field - and I think we have an ethical responsibility to look at the systematic mechanisms that reproduce that situation and change them.
column32: I work within the US, which is a settler state. The Principles as they stand simply do not engage in the politics of archaeology in a settler state in any systematic or deep way. It is not especially responsible to Indigenous perspectives or claims.
column34: Again, the Principles are good at addressing issues within a narrow scope of preservation and expert knowledge. I always work to help my students understand why these considerations do matter, although they (rightly I think) tend to take issue with the erasure of Indigenous perspectives and claims.

column9:
Register of Professional Archaeologists
As director of the state's division of archaeology and very involved in SHPO practices, we occasionally refer to ethical standards in discussions of data access, consultation, and best practices.
column10:
Being transparent about what your, or your project, is doing with all the relevant parties, and doing so in way that makes them actual participants and not someone you talk to after everything is decided..  Not really a problem for most 106 projects as that process usually (!) manages to include the right players in a timely way.  But I think archaeologists still have a significant challenge consulting with tribal communities on non-106 projects.  There is still a strong tendency to develop the project scope and plan of operation before reaching out to other possible partners and asking them to join.  This doesn't provide them the opportunity to join in the development and help make the project what they want it to be.
At the same time, while my current role is telling archaeologists how they can meet the SHPO's expectations while accommodating tribal expectations as well, if I were to develop my own personal research project (retirement?), I would certainly let the appropriate Tribes know of my plans, but I am not sure how I would react if one or more of them had significant concerns about the proposal.  Certainly would talk with them about it, but at what level am i willing to give them veto power over what I do - no answer to this (yet).

One of the standard phrases in 106 is 'making a reasonable and good faith effort'.  it is not always clear what that should entail.  While our office has developed field and report standards as one means to address that, you can't cover every situation.  what are the ethical implications of this standard?
Where I run into this often is in dealing with unmarked and abandoned cemeteries.  What level of effort is 'right' when trying to find descendent communities who should participate in decisions impacting their ancestors graves (tribal, slave, or other).  Especially in the case of slave or 19th century rural family cemeteries where there is no obvious descendent population?
I often find myself thinking of the 'reasonable and good faith' standard as essentially coming down to "can I defend my actions in court".  Have never been called into court to defend, but this is how i often find myself assessing the effort.  Is the fear of court a reasonable ethical standard to use?
column12: my only concern is that the way it is worded seems to imply that archaeologists are the ones that 'control' the archaeological record, and that fails to acknowledge that other parties have an equal interest and ownership, and that preservation/protection should require working with those communities in a mutual preservation effort.  But the statement does capture what I think archaeologists should be responsible for.
column14:
the challenge here is what is meant by 'consult with'.  
Does this mean simply telling them what you are going to do and asking them to join, or, does it mean involving them at the beginning of project conception and design so that they become partners whose interests guide the research as much as your own?  Not applicable in all situations of course.
column26: According to a recent discussion on the Nat. Assoc of State Archs, this is a real problem.  I think this a ultimately a problem of grad schools (not) teaching ethics because I think there is a perception that if you get a MA/PhD degree, then you're qualified to do archaeology anywhere of any kind.  And it is something I see in my job all the time, folks not having the experience/training to tackle specific types of sites.  From the standpoint of an 'ethical standard', not really sure what can be done about it.
column28: my concern here is that the standard is 'obeying the law'.  One could argue that as a citizen, or researcher in a foreign country, you are required to do that anyway.  Surely the standard should be treating people right.
column30: I think one issue the standards don't address (but the RPA standards do to some degree) are the challenges of working in the private business world.  SAA needs to recognize that the vast majority of US archaeologists work in private industry and have to contend with demands of clients and federal agencies in carrying out their work.  There is no discussion in the current standards of what one should do when one's professional obligations (as set forth by these standards) are challenged by a client who doesn't want to pay for something, or who refuses to allow you to follow accepted practice.  what is the ethical standard when you have to balance one's professional standards against what you are allowed to do?

column10: To rectify the human rights abuses committed by archaeologists on indigenous peoples: the consent of descendant communities must be sought prior to disturbing the material evidence of their presence on the land; indigenous peoples must be offered the right to participate in archaeological field work, excavation, analysis, and curation of material record of their own culture; indigenous perspectives must be given priority over non-indigenous views in analysis, publication, and in interpretive materials.
column14: In light of the power relationships established via the ethnocide committed against Native peoples, this statement on accountability needs to be more specific. What is an effect, and who get to define the term? Who gets to decide when there has been an effect? Who gets to decide who to consult with in answering these questions? Will this draft statement be circulated among Native governments for review? And would their comments be taken seriously?
column18: Placing Native Americans in the slot of a "public" here ignores their right to own and interpret their own past. They are not part of a "public" as determined by this organization. Rather, the public/private binary used here is a perpetuation of a long process of expropriation and delegitimization of Native peoples and their own culture. Abandon this flawed binary by using the term "sovereign nations" when referring to Naive Americans. Do not put them in the same bag as the general public.
column20: Not disagreeing with the sentiment, but this is unrealistic on the count of fairness. The playing field is not level -- some researchers have access to more resources (financial, organizational, networks, etc.) to publish than others. Perhaps co-authorship is a better model than simply giving up your work to another researcher.
column26: Again, not disagreeing with the sentiment, but this is too weak. Why does SAA seemingly never promote the professional licensing of archaeologists? My dog groomer has a professional license. Why undersell ourselves here?  And, listing on the RPA registry is not a professional license.

column10: 1) Conserving archaeological sites and materials; 2) addressing descendant community concerns; 3) educating the public about archaeological ethics and descendant community concerns without debasing members of the public and their existing ethics.
column16: If a privately owned archaeological site is being or will be adversely affected by looting or land use, and archaeologists are given an opportunity to investigate and recover information and/or limited samples of archaeological material from the site before or during the adverse action, archaeologists should be able to do so without their ethics being questioned. In other words, there are some situations where "salvage" archaeology should be practiced, even if the discovered archaeological material ultimately will end up in private collections.
column20: Information about archaeological sites and material on Indian land or private land should be considered the intellectual property of the Indian tribe or private landowner only, and the tribe or landowner should not be required to allow any researcher to have any access to original materials and documents or to make those materials and documents available to others unless - in the case of private land only - there is a federal, state, or local government nexus that requires archaeological studies be done prior to the involved government agency's issuance of a permit, license, government funding, or clearance for a proposed action to proceed.
column22: This principle should not apply to archaeological sites and material on Indian land or private land unless the occupying tribe or private land owner agrees that the acquired knowledge can be presented to others or stored in a public repository unless - in the case of private land only - there is a federal, state, or local government nexus that requires archaeological studies be done prior to the involved government agency's issuance of a permit, license, government funding, or clearance for a proposed action to proceed.
column30: I agree the SAA Principles of Ethics satisfactorily address most situations archaeologists find themselves in today, but need to be updated to address intellectual property and the rights of Indian tribes and private landowners with regard to archaeological sites and materials on Indian and private land.

column16: I think this is an incredibly complicated that we as archaeologists have over simplified. Our aversion to reaching out groups (such as metal detectorists, collectors, and avocational archaeologists) that engage with these activities have created hostility, lack of knowledge sharing, and actually increased the problem. Also, archaeologists who work in museums are never trained in how to understand the monetary value of objects. This makes us ill equipped to do certain aspects of our job, like determine insurance value for objects being loaned or transported, develop appropriate collections management policies that comply with museum practices, etc. We can say we're against buying and selling things, while also recognize that the people that do that have knowledge that is important to harness and that knowing the value of something can be essential for some professional archaeologists.

column12: I believe that preservation and stewardship are outdated terms that reify western ideals of managing heritage as static entity to be preserved in stasis for the future. This does a poor job of accounting for the living nature of heritage and explicitly excludes practices that engage in changing aspects of heritage sites in an ongoing manner. This perspective also doesn't account for the impossibility of preserving everything. A principle that allows for a more critical engagement with the idea of preservation and sees heritage management as more dynamic is more appropriate today.
column28: This should go further to provide explicit minimum standards that are clearer and more stringent than many local standards.
column30: I think that the standards do not deal well with the challenges of sexual discrimination or harassment. I also think that the preservation ethic embodied in Principle 1 is no longer universally defensible.

column43: This survey question is strange. I think separate documents make sense as one represents and aspirational code, while the other presents enforceable standards. This can be used to more clearly separate management of different varieties of ethical challenges. The ethical practice of archaeology relating to the engagement of stakeholder communities, engagement of the public, and management of heritage are aspirational concerns. In contrast, the management of discrimination, sexual harassment/assault, and the appropriate treatment of field crews are specific issues that should strongly regulated with enforceable consequences.

column20: I strongly agree with the first two sentences.  But, I do not think there is general, wide spread agreement on what "a limited and reasonable time" is.  I have seen academic researchers tie up collections for years by requesting them through loans for years, as they struggle to conclude their research.  They drag their feet, or are completely oblivious to requests for returning the material so that others can access it.  This is a principle that appears to be systematically abused.

To many reports which could present useful, cutting edge information languish until their publication becomes a postscript to research that has moved on.
column24: Archaeologists should also STRONGLY encourage colleagues, students, etc., to deposit the records they produce during the course of their studies in a central facility, where others may make use of them.  And as responsible stewards of the archaeological record, they should also encourage their colleagues to deposit all collections, artifacts and records, in a timely fashion, at a central facility, where they will remain available and accessible for research for decades to come.

column10:
The continued use of sexist narratives and talking points within archaeology, eg: a particular site being "sexy" or the idea that fieldwork is a "boys club"

The increasing amount of sexual harassment and violence reported by students and professionals in the field- holding men (it's almost always men) who sexually harass or assault people accountable 

The concern for respecting Indigenous sovereignty in pre-contact archaeology, being increasingly respectful of human remains and culturally-sensitive materials and lands; we should be trying to empower Indigenous peoples through our work and that includes increasing opportunities for Indigenous youth to become involved with the practice and narrative of archaeology. 

I guess in a general sense, the primary ethical concern for archaeology going forwards should be to vulnerable communities, especially those who have been negatively affected by racial and class structures in the U.S.

column26: This may be an unpopular opinion but I think that this principle is too important to rely on Field Schools to teach students- Field School programs are increasingly expensive and many undergraduate programs are overly focused on sending students abroad to "exciting" places rather than focusing on the skills that are most necessary- in this way I think that more undergrad programs should have classes geared towards training students with field methods so that they are ready to hop into a career even if they can't afford a proper field school. column10:
The lack of consequences to those that break ethical codes. In other disciplines that have to obtain license, the breaking of ethical codes results in the loss of the licenses, thus loss of a career. In archaeology, if you are not a member of an  organization, you do not need to follow any ethical standard and can continue to practice archaeology. IF you break and ethical code and are found guilty, you are simply removed from the organization with no ramification to the individuals career.

The issue with the SAA code is that there is no ethical obligations to colleagues and employers. We, as archaeologists in SAA consider ourselves professional but have no ethical code regarding how we interact or treat or work with our colleagues, employers or students.

SAA also has a weak Safe Educational and Workplace Environments code. A safe environemnt is more than sexual harassment. Again, no clear ramifications for violating the code.
column14: This should be linked to the applicable local, national, and international laws on consultation.

column10:
Equality based on race, gender, ethnicity.  Specific adherence to ARPA and NAGPRA.  Going beyond NAGPRA to develop meaningful and sustainable relationships with tribes and indigenous communities.  Engagement of tribal and descendant communities in our work, hearing and including their voice and histories - written, drawn and oral.  Including tribal and descendant community participation through paid contracting, internships, etc - do not "invite to volunteer" but engage and an equal when relevant.

Sexual discrimination and harassment.  Having been on the receiving end of unwanted sexual harrassment by a faculty member during my MA as well as discrimination over years as a female in the field (I specialize in geohysical survyes - beginning in the 1990s there were a few women involved, many more so now - but speaking to my experience) - I feel specific training / ethics requirements must be developed and required for RPA, academic faculty and students, CRM, etc (I assume State and Fed agencies have their own ethics training).

 2) explain and promote the use of archaeological methods and techniques in understanding human behavior and culture - with care not to encourage folks to "dig" or metal detect.  Specific guidance on communication and use of metal detection should be included.

3) communicate archaeological interpretations of the past.  Many publics exist for archaeology including students and teachers; Native Americans and other ethnic, religious, and cultural groups who find in the archaeological record important aspects of their cultural heritage; lawmakers and government officials; reporters, journalists, and others involved in the media; and the general public. 

This text is not clear.  (publics is not a word?)  3) specific text in regard to arch interpretations of the past - that include the many components of the occupation and use of a landscape; must include all voices not just the archeologists - all voices in relation to the archeological record - de-colonization of the interpretation/intpretor

column9: World Archaeological Congress, especially in terms of repatriation in teaching classes on issues in cultural property and introduction to museum studies.  Society for Historical Archaeology, Register of Professional Archaeologists, European Association of Archaeologists in preparation of expert witness testimony for a CRM case involving ethics and performance standards.
column10: Principle 2, accountability is still at the top of my list especially to Indigenous and other marginalized groups. We still use the word consult, but really need to move toward collaboration instead. Certainly, there is also a link of 5, Intellectual Property, which we still define in terms of rights of the archaeologist rather than those whose past or contemporary lives we might be studying. The definition of stewardship still defines sites, materials, etc. in terms of being beneficial to all people, but really protecting ourselves. Finally we need better understandings of how we treat students and colleagues, from the time we are students through their lifetimes as colleagues or just interested members of the public, which relates to principles 4 & 8.
column12: This goes back a long time because it is a self-declaration of archaeologists as a having  primary role as stewards and declares especially that the archaeological record is for the benefit of all people, which isn't always seen that way by marginalized people. It can be if they are wiling to allow it, which demands our recognition as archaeologists that the people we study should be viewed as primary in decision-making when our work impinges on their pasts.
column14: We are slowly learning that accountability means something beyond consultation and our training should reflect that. Who defines what a reasonable effort is? Or good faith?
column16: In some cases we need to sort out commercialization from other issues related to matters in the last line. Certainly, I support the  matter of not commercializing objects, the sale of which cause destruction of sites by looters and the like. But for other concerns, there may be very reasonable objections to display of or curation of human remains or sacred objects, which goes well beyond NAGPRA's stated regulations. Largely, the way the last line is written privileges scientific investigation, public access, and so forth. We keep people from having access to specific site locations, so why can't we specifically declare that it is reasonable for other materials or knowledge?
column18: Generally, this is good, but there may be reasons not to communicate beyond a group with a vested interest in keeping certain knowledge out of the public domain, or to be certain that what we are educating others about doesn't diminish their own stories or somehow provide incorrect information.
column20: Mostly agreed, but intellectual property should in many cases belong to the  the group from which it is derived. See the IPinCH (Intellectual Property in Cultural Heritage) web site for issues. https://www.sfu.ca/ipinch/   This project has hard-earned perspectives that every archaeologist should know about.
column22: Yes, we need to report what we do as archaeologists, but accessibility and intellectual property rights need to be acknowledged need to be clearly spelled out.
column24: Generally agreed, though with increasing issues related to collection curation, we need to have guidance  about practice, not just aspiration. In other words, our hopes and goals about access may need to be adjusted by recognition of realities of space, funding, and the like.
column26: Yes, but training includes much more than methods of getting stuff out of the ground and analyzed and/or curated and reported. We also need training in associated aspects related to collaboration and how to do it effectively as well as how to evaluate it. Almost everything in the existing principle is about the "science" but should be more.
column28: As the most current principle and with the recent history of events in the discipline, this is the most up-to-date in terms of our hopes for the discipline.
column30: The principles, while not negative particularly, do not reflect the changing nature of the field, especially in terms of our accountability to groups beyond our own profession, which are only vaguely mentioned.
column32: For reasons already stated
column34: I do a lot of work with marginalized people, and our current principles are almost antithetical to that work.
column42: Separate Principles of Ethics and Standards of Practice
column43: I have found the Register of Professional Archaeologists' structure of having standards of practice useful . aspirational codes provide some guidance, but primarily used to show our publics that we are "nice people" and to use these to advocate for our discipline. We need more to show us how to achieve those hopes. Actually, I think that all ethics codes need to be living documents. Sometimes aspirations "lock you in" and become unachievable, even detrimental (as was the SAA position on repatriation and reburial, and even some resistance to NAGPRA regulations). Living documents allow you to "let go" of ethics principles that prove to be harmful to the discipline or to others.

column10: Sexual harassment in archaeological field work and academic work, diversity of the professorship, and how to better empower local communities through archaeological work
column14: I believe that responsible archaeological research is not the one that simply consults actively with the affected groups. It is also the one that engages these groups where possible in the decision making process, the one that discusses its goals with the affected groups to find a way that archaeology can be beneficial to them (also achieving the groups' goals).That can be done with public education, but also with involving the affected groups in the stewardship process.
column20: Disregards the issues of indigenous and community intellectual property when archaeologists make use of their material culture and experiences in the research and interpretation process.
column22: This principle does express the need for making the archaeological record presented accessibly, but the efforts have not match to the principle. The SAA should discuss ways to better encourage archaeologists to publish their research outside of academic journals as the lack of accessibility to scientific knowledge has already been addressed multiple times.
column28: In the previous surveys by the SAA referring specifically to sexual harassment, and as addressed in numerous studies on the topic of sexual harassment and assault in academia (even if in areas other than archaeology and anthropology), it has been clear that national and workplace laws and policies have failed to promote safety to students, trainees, and professionals. With the recent changes on Title IX by the current administration, the safety of educational and workplace settings is even more hindered.The SAA can encourage professionals, departments, and professionals to establish their own policies against discrimination, sexual harassment and assault. Departments can establish more clear paths of reporting, professors in the labs and during their field programs can have conversations with their students and assistants about what to do in case of harassment/assault/discrimination. The responsibility is on archaeologists in position of power to establish a safe environment, but students and trainees can also be provided resources through the SAA on how to have conversations with their professors and supervisors to make these policies clear in their specific educational and workspace environments.
column30: The principles already established are general, and this can be understood considering its nature is to be general. However, the SAA could broaden the principles into best practices and guidelines that can guide how these principles should look like in practice. This is specially important for issues of intellectual property, community engagement/public education, and as it relates to discrimination and sexual harassment. Encouraging professionals, professors, departments, and private archaeology groups to develop more efficient policies and execution of sites and lab work to protect students and professionals from discrimination and harassment.
column32: There are many issues as it relates to the barriers to research and professional training put by governments that were not addresses in these principles. How to abide to them in case of lack of resources and governmental support for the practice?

column12: One archaeological sites, records, and artifacts are damaged or destroyed, and once information is separated from its referents (such as artifacts in private collections and on the market), there's no getting it back. Gone forever. Stewardship of the archaeological record for future generations, particularly descendant communities, is our top priority.
column14: Archaeological research should not be for profit, personal gain, or mere entertainment. It's a group activity in which inclusion and accountability are extremely important.
column16: well stated.
column18: I agree as stated, but this is not something that EVERY archaeologist is good at or can devote significant time to. It's really important for the SAA to encourage education specialists and to encourage everyone to work together toward this goal. So I think the last sentence is very important here.
column20: amazing how many archaeologists sit on data till they die, and then it gets lost or can't be used. This is changing, thanks largely to CRM, but academia needs work on this. Few universities give a hoot about faculty's legacy data or collections. And there are so many Federal collections that need curation but agencies aren't funded to handle it, and yet federal grants can't be used to process them. The whole problem of legacy data, collections, archives, and orphan collections is neglected.
column22: YES. Funding is a barrier to curation/deposition for legacy collections, but for new research, all this should be in place before beginning work.
column24: well stated. Extremely important.
column26: well stated. Can't do any of the previous without training, facilities, support.
column28: again, unbelievable and truly that sexual harassment and assault are still prevalent in our discipline (and all the field sciences). We need to change the culture. Survivors should be supported when they speak up about violations. SAA could offer supervisor skills trainings. Field schools, universities, and CRM firms should do so as well. SAA can help link supervisors to effective resources.
column30: I think so. I didn't go with "strongly" here only because I am sure there are other situations that arise from time to time that are very important to those who find themselves in difficulty. The current pandemic adds to job insecurity, looting, obstacles to career advancement of various kinds, and I am sure other concerns will arise. But I think this covers the main things, and the persistent areas of concern.
column32: This covers it, except that income disparity and job insecurity are increasing in ways I don't think we are equipped to address as a nation much less as a profession.
column34: except for exploitation of contingent faculty, decreasing resources for students, and rising instability in the whole academic "enterprise."
column36: I expect that more could and perhaps should be said about the imperative for collaboration with descendant communities. It's in there, but is it emphasized emphatically enough?
column42: An aspirational code,Separate Principles of Ethics and Standards of Practice,Ethical document(s) that provides examples
column43: I worry that the living document becomes no more than a conversation that's negotiable. I worry that SAA is really not in a position to enforce the behavior of others (there is no license to practice that can be revoked, for example, and then there's the question of resources to invest in investigation and adjudication). But there should be some enforcement--being barred from taking part in meetings due to a history of harassing behavior or assault, for example. Having membership revoked for egregious and well-documented illegal behavior, such as looting, for example. But recommending best practices, offering training and resources, and setting a high standard for professional behavior is all do-able and important.

column43:
The AAA example has not been recently updated and I believe this demonstrates a weakness of this "living document." I have regularly checked the AAA website re: their code of ethics and this is the first I have heard of this "forum."
I think that interest groups within SAA (along with the annual meeting) are appropriate fora for discussion of ethical examples and issues. In my opinion our field is too diverse to be guided by specific ethical documents or detailed standards of practice. For archaeological fieldwork, states have standards and guidelines. Institutions/work settings usually have their own standards of practice, and so forth. I cannot imagine a committee that would include perspectives from all of the training and work settings experienced by archaeologists today, and so I cannot imagine how separate ethical documents could be effectively designed, much less implemented,

column12: Some of the archaeological record is more in need of preservation than other materials.
column16: "potentially enhancing the commercial value" should not be a factor that reduces archaeological investigation and public education. It may be true that increased public awareness results in commercialization, but that shouldn't prevent us from doing research. The way this is worded makes it seem like we have to be secretive about what we do, which will backfire by contributing to the black market appeal of artifacts as forbidden fruit.
column26: This principle should also include a proscription on research undertaken in situations when the goals could reasonably be obtained using previously investigated/excavated materials. Use of extant collections should be a primary practice in training situations.
column28: I think the principle absolutely belongs here, but the wishy-washy phrasing is not helpful. All the text telling us to "follow existing laws" sidesteps the real ethical concerns. You might just as well replace most of the earlier principles by citing the antiquities act and leaving it there. It's not enough to just say this is covered elsewhere. The ethics of personal responsibility and safe environments needs to be clearly spelled out. This principle should stand on its own as a standard to hold each of us to. When someone violates it, that should be clear from the way the principle is written. As it is now, it seems like a placeholder that shifts responsibility to the legal system. SAA needs to be able to sanction members who don't follow ethical standards separately from whether they are technically legal or not. It's probably not technically illegal to take 30 years to report on an excavation, but the ethics of those situations are clear here. This should be the same. Contributing to a work environment that causes subordinates to feel unsafe needs to be specifically prohibited, and those who do so should be held to account whether or not their actions accord with "the laws and policies of their home nation." Are you saying that people from nations with poor records of civil rights are free to come here and harass people because it's fine where they are from? Of course not, that's obvious, but that kind of inconsistency and failure to clearly spell out what's ok and what's not too often results in failure to take action in situations where young women are put in impossible situations during their training without apparent recourse and threats to their ability to pursue their research.
column30: The principle of promoting public knowledge is set against the fact that public interest has a sordid commercialist side. The importance of personal responsibility for conduct with coworkers is not sufficiently made clear.
column36: The importance of adequate collections management is touched on in a couple of the Principles, but it is one of our worst current failures of stewardship. I think that could stand on its own as a specific responsibility.

column12: This sentiment is excellent, but I wish that it included a brief phrase that makes it clear that the needs of living people can at times be more important than preservation. As it is written, it could be used to make an argument for preservation regardless of the needs of a descendent community. The case of the Zuni war gods, which are intended to weather/decompose provides an excellent example of how "advocating for the archaeological record for the benefit of all people" can result in a harmful emphasis on "universal" histories.
column20: "for a limited and reasonable time" is very vague and open to many interpretations. Also, I don't have strong feelings about intellectual property.
column22: I'm not sure if there is a good way around it, but the phrase "reasonable time" is awfully vague.
column26: STANDARDS need to be outlined somewhere. People definitely graduate students who should not be allowed to conduct any kind of destructive analysis.
column28:
Needs consequences. Also, knowing the laws and consequences of their home nation and institutional workplace is not enough. They do need to know this, but there should also be a statement from SAA about OUR standards. Ethical principles should require more than just following someone else's rules. It should also clearly apply to everyone, not just supervisors. It is everyone's responsibility to prevent and harassment. Terms also need to be defined by SAA, not just by other institutions. 

I think that the RPA guidelines are much better in this respect. Here they are:

"An archaeologist’s responsibility is to create a safe work environment free of harassment of all types, including sexual. Sexual harassment in this Code is defined as a pattern of unwanted advances, references, or remarks of a physical or sexual nature when an individual has expressed that such advances, references, or remarks are unwelcome.
 
"An archaeologist shall not engage in sexual, gender, and any other form of harassment or violence (including verbal, symbolic, or physical) against any colleague, student, employee, employer, sponsor, or member of the public in the conduct of archaeological practice. An archaeologist shall intervene when witnessing such behavior by others. Intervention is important as it substantiates claims made by those who are victims while reducing the likelihood of retaliation."
column30: They're a solid start, but they need some work and updating.

column10: Many archaeologists as well as funding organizations continue to prioritize work based on "broader impacts," and treat the archaeological record as scientific specimens with little regard for modern or past descendant communities. SAA needs to take a firmer stance on what it means for archaeologists to ethically engage with diverse publics. We need to adopt critical heritage perspectives and abandon perspectives and narratives that treat archaeological materials as national or universal features of heritage.

column16:
Grey areas include publishing that demonstrates the importance or uniqueness of artifacts and collections.  That is often an essential part of documentation and interpretation,  but is also used by collectors and sellers to validate items for sale. 

It is also tricky to deal with requests to identify (NOT appraise) artifacts for the general public.  We don’t want to alienate people with a genuine interest but it is difficult to know how that info will be used.
