column24:
This is a huge infrastructural problem for a great number of privately contracted CRM. Projects.    Preserving these records and collections in a way that makes them useable - in perpetuity-  Is really a full time, specialized job.  There are absolutely not nearly enough repositories or museums to manage this.   We all have horror stories about collections in people’s garages.   

I see this as a critical aspirational goal for the discipline, and it will take a huge infrastructural effort  To actually make it possible for this ethical responsibility to be met
column26: Particularly when it comes to adequate fiscal and interdisciplinary support.  Doing a field school because it is cost effective does not work if the funds for environmental and other specialists are lacking,  or the skill and equipment for geospatial mapping and recording aren’t there

column12: This is aspirational, for sure. In reality American Archaeologist working in academia are encouraged to take young and inexperienced students to exotic locales for fieldwork. Any 'data' recovered is horded by the directors and used to advanced that institutions viewpoint, like voting for your favorite theory through manipulation of the publishing system (see Bintliff, 2011). I wish American archaeologists were more up front concerning the embedded status of academia within the Capitalist socio-economic system. Even worse, the shady situational ethics of Survivor Island have infected academia like cancer. Every month a new scandal rocks the social sciences [Niall Ferguson's fall from Harvard's graces over petty departmental social warfare, fabricated spider data, published papers 'recalled' 'voluntarily' by suddenly ethical researchers and so on].
column14: I agree that many different parties have stakes in archaeological research. I have worked at some well-known (hence, profitable) archaeological sites and found myself embroiled in local politics several times. This is an interesting point, but a complex conundrum on the ground. I remember excavating monuments that later went to a local museum, only to have the central government send trucks to move the monuments to the capital, 900km away. I did not want to monuments to make the journey and saw the protests at the museum when locals demanded that their cultural patrimony remain local. The archaeologists in charge of the recoveries were never consulted, which led to more animosity. There were different cultural groups speaking different languages, local and federal officials making constant demands [grifts and grafts] etc. This reality was never covered in any book or class at any university I attended.
column16: Again, American Archaeology is embedded with the Capitalist system and must abide by those rules, stated or understood. This survey is looking a bit naive at this point. Of course, archaeologists should not profiteer, though I doubt reading an ethics statement will bring morality back to the profession.
column20: I agree, but this will not occur without extreme pressure to change the existing academic model. I am currently writing up the final report for my deceased mentor's work (he would have been 100 next year). I am aware that my mentor's students also fell behind on publishing, one died without completing their final report, another is working with me, still.
column24: Again, completely aspirational. I have been blocked from seeing collections, even by legal order.
column26: Penn State University destroyed a wonderful archaic rock shelter in Honduras (El Gigante) by sending a single, inexperienced grad student to excavate the site. To this day the data cannot be unscrambled. However, I am sure that a fantasy publication with emerge, constructed from old notes and partial data files by students that never saw the work in the first place. My own advisor at Penn State was livid that no one could access the corrupt data on his 5.25" floppy discs. Justs hands me an archaic data storage disc oblivious to the fact that no one had even seen one in over a decade!

column10: This will be an unpopular answer, but the growing number of self-proclaimed activist archaeologists is dangerous.  These folks often put their agenda before their mid-range theory and academic rigor.  They also diminish the profession by making all these claims about what archaeology can and must do.  They inevitably fail.  Having said archaeology must be activism or it is nothing at all, having failed to solve any major world problem (have failed in their activism), where does that leave the profession?  How do we justify archaeology when so many are preaching that only activist archaeology counts?  The half-assed liberalism -- I can solve the world problems of mass migration by synthesizing archaeological studies of migration, or I can make racism go away by proclaiming myself an activist archaeologist or I can eliminate world sexism by donning my Activist Archaeology cape -- is dangerous and leads to poor archaeology.  It also oversells what archaeology can and should do, and that sets us up for the weakening or elimination of Section 106 and such.

column20: If you receive public funds or tax breaks as being non-profit then there should be transparency on all levels, fairly rapidly. Private corporations conducting archaeological assessments and generating data should not be held to this standard. Information should be allowed to be viewed by accredited individuals in a peer review situation if there are concerns.  These peer reviews should be represented by professionals without an allegiance to the contractor generating the report or entity wishing to impact the area. Information regarding this should be made public in a redacted form to make the public aware there are potential challenges, but no specific information should be made readily available to the public without proper consideration to preserve integrity in the event impact is averted. In the instance of areas that will be adversely impacted without significant findings environmental assessments and such should made immediately available once construction is completed but not prior to construction to the public.

column10:
While there is tremendous work by many professionals in the arena of public education and engagement--there is still more to be done to keep in touch with the many publics who are stakeholders in our work.

I believe there is more to be done to encourage and enable scholars to use collections of material culture already in repositories. There is still a strong bias toward field projects defining careers and success in the discipline.

The sustainability of our archaeological undertaking needs more attention, particularly on the subject of stewarding collections and supporting documentation in perpetuity. More advocacy for collections holding institutions and the resources that they need is essential to preserve the archaeological record.

In the first go round of the Ethical Principles--there was not a principle of scholarship and integrity. I have always found that to be a glaring oversight given it is a basic tenant of the education we all received, but never explicitly enshrined in the principles.

There are still inherent inequities in the academy, in agencies, and in other organizations where archaeologists work. There is still much to do in creating fair professional relationships between those in the profession whose positions grant them more power over those whose positions place them in positions of less power, particularly with regards to the access of opportunities and resources.
column34:
I work in a museum setting within a private research institute. There are ethical principles that museum professionals uphold, promulgated in codes of ethics laid out by organizations of museum professionals, that are not encompassed by the SAA Principles of Ethics. Those codes of ethics are important and binding upon us and our work.

As many archaeologists are called to work in living communities, some of the ethical principles laid out by the American Anthropological Association merit closer inclusion in the SAA Principles, particularly the AAA's principles 1-4.

column28:
Interesting that that this is defined as supervisors fulfilling an objective of making a safe environment for younger students and trainees. While that's no doubt a laudable goal, and of course such crimes are indeed prevalent in settings where there is a disparity in interpersonal power dynamics, is it only for the sake of the young that we should act appropriately and respectfully? What about inappropriate acts against one's older colleagues? What about between younger peers, neither of which is yet a "responsible supervisor?" Why specify just work or educational settings? Archaeologists are often forced into close quarters off site and after hours, be it a field house, hotels, etc.

Urging archaeologists to follow the law and be respectful seems inadequate to the problem at hand, especially in light of the recent research by Meyers identifying the prevalence of sexual harassment in our field in particular. SAA should embrace recent objective studies and research on this topic in a comprehensive policy.

column10:
I think this is a difficult question to answer because so many of the SAA's principles are interrelated.
For social and political reasons I think that accountability should be every archaeologists' primary ethical concern. Anthropology and archaeology are colonial fields in the United States, the power dynamics are not even, and it is up to archaeologists to be aware of the destructive nature of our science and how that affects other groups (especially indigenous groups).
For the field/science itself I think that stewardship and public education/outreach are primary ethical concerns. Stewardship on all fronts would be improved if all archaeologists were invested in public education and outreach (I'm thinking in particular of in situ archaeological protection and conservation). I also believe that not enough archaeologists are invested in the long-term protection of the archaeological record after it has been dug up.... collection management is something that all of us should be invested in.
column12: I think that this principle could be made more explicit when it comes to the ethical obligation of archaeologists to plan for and implement long-term collections care.
column14:
I think that this principle very much reads as if it is from 1996 and doesn't go far enough to address the ethical implications of archaeological work on affected groups who have less power in our society. The first principle of the American Anthropological Association is "Do no harm." That principle explicitly states "Anthropologists should not only avoid causing direct and immediate harm but also should weigh carefully the potential consequences and inadvertent impacts of their work. When it conflicts with other responsibilities, this primary obligation can supersede the goal of seeking new knowledge and can lead to decisions to not undertake or to discontinue a project." 
I don't think it is unreasonable for this to be a principle for the SAA as well. After-all how are we going to be able to engage with other ethical principles like stewardship, outreach, etc. if we have burned all our bridges?
column18: I think that if we actually care about any of the other principles education and public outreach are imperative. I think it is a bit of a cop out to imply that archaeologists are "unable to undertake public education and outreach directly." There are so many ways to do public outreach/education, and I think it should be a priority for every archaeologist to engage with this in some way (not saying that everyone needs to be giving this their all one hundred percent of the time, but they shouldn't be let off the hook when it comes to thinking about and engaging with this in some way).
column24: I think this principle is hugely important and should be given more weight. Can we more explicitly addresses the implications of not engaging in long-term conservation and collections plans and/or engagement in collections based research?
column28: It should also be a responsibility for archaeologists to ensure that students and trainees are provided appropriate information that allows them to: 1) know their rights; 2) provides them with information on what to do and who to contact if their rights are violated by the supervisor or someone else on a project.
column30: I agree overall, although I think the language could be made more explicit.
column32: I do not think the principles go far enough to address the underlying power dynamics and imbalances in our field/society.

column16: The first half of this statement and the latter half do not jive for me. Archaeologists should be discouraging the buying and selling of objects, but the focus on the latter half is contributing to the creation of value.  If our work is seen by the public, it will potentially result in value increasing.  That should be combated with statements against looting/selling, not by making the project silent or not doing the project in the first place.  If publicizing that there is archaeological sites in Brazil rainforest creates a market for Brazil artifacts or people seeking sites there, that is bad. But new areas of exploration should not be avoided simply because it can create or increase a market. Those are not 1:1 issues.  I would rather the latter half of this statement discuss if and how archaeologists should combat this, not weighing if their work can be exploited by looters.

I think we also need to acknowledge that there are other means of understanding the archaeological record, and in some cases, descendant communities may have cultural practices and beliefs that run counter to an archaeological preservation ethic.

I think it's also important to note that often when we talk about preservation we're not talking about preservation in situ but excavation and documentation - which is a form of destruction - and is so prevalent in current consumptive models of HRM. I'm not sure it's always the right approach even though it's the industry standard. I'd like to see something in the principles explicitly differentiates between the two and acknowledges the shortcomings of the latter.

—Teaching students that the profession of archaeology actually does have ethical standards.
—Holding professors to those same standards, especially concerning fieldwork and artifact collection and NAGPRA issues on federal lands.

column18:
Also must be included:  Archaeologists must obtain the required federal and state permits to work on federal and state lands.  

We have encountered situations where at least one academic archaeologist paid private collectors to collect paleo Indian projectile points and other artifacts from federal lands.  Not only did he not have a permit to work on federal lands, but he also committed innumerable ARPA violations.  Through a plea agreement, only the collectors themselves were subjected to prosecution for this crime.  The academic himself received NO punishment.  There was no mechanism through either the SAA or ROPA to hold him accountable.  

Archaeologists need to be aware that their research activities are regulated on state and federal lands and internationally.  To date, the scope of federal and state regulations often appears to be unacknowledged or unknown, especially by academic archaeologists.
column26: The need for adequate curation of both records and artifacts/samples needs to be more clearly articulated and emphasized.

column10: There are really two threads here, the ethics of how we approach the archaeological record and how we approach other archaeologists. column10: A general resistance to ethics. It seems to me that the concerns are many, but can be generally lumped into the categories of diversity and gender. As we have seen, sexual harassment is a major problem, but we have done very little to address it. Why? The inability to support and enforce our ethics is a real problem. Ethics mean nothing if there is no enforcement mechanism. As far as I can tell there has been no reduction in sexual harassment after including it in the Principles. So, how do you give it "teeth"? It is a major problem for the discipline. I don't feel comfortable encouraging my students to go into the field and can only encourage them to go certain field schools (mostly because I know the directors or they have very clear statements AND mechanisms for addressing harassment). IFR is also no longer one of them, which means that there is almost no centralized field school tool. This is all because of a general ethics malaise that has infiltrated the field because we cannot ensure that our own ethics are being followed.
column12: Stewardship is not just about the archaeological record. I would like to see something added about how "good relationships" (better terms needed) with communities is a type of "stewardship" because it enables the protection of sites. BTW I recognize that this is in subsequent principles, but these are hierarchical (most everything falls under 1). Bringing this into principle one stresses that our endeavor is not just about protecting things.
column16: I would change the wording of this to include some statement that would include companies (e.g. Christies or Hobby Lobby). column18: But, perhaps this could also stress the importance of research about "underrepresented" groups.
column28: This should be stronger. It really passes all responsibility off and says that people should follow the law. Well, duh. That's not exactly an ethical statement. column43: The Principles as they stand are broad and general. This is helpful sometimes, but there is no "meat" to them. That is, think of the Principles as the backbone (like the Constitution, for example) that is difficult to use in daily life. We need both generality and clarity. Perhaps those are two different documents. However, both should be "living documents". Maybe it's harder to change the Principles and there is an easier to change, more specific and applicable document. I don't think that this is an either or situation. Both should be living. But, because of the importance of that broader document (presumably some version of the Principles) to the "Standards of Practice" document the former should be more stable (but not "dead").

column16: In Texas, professional archeologist must reach out to artifact collectors to try and find ways to stem the tide of "Pay to Dig" sites. The crisis is Texas is that there are increasing numbers of "Pay to Dig" sites where backhoes are used to dig up deposits so people can screen them and take home the artifacts. Most people who participate are good people who simply enjoy the thrill of finding arrowheads. Most of them want to learn more about what they are finding, and they have no idea that what they are doing is destroying the very information that they wish to learn. Many of them could (and have) become avocational archeologists if they were exposed to better information and opportunities to do "real archeology."
column22:
The need to protect sites by limiting site location information in public reports is real, but common sense should prevail over an strict adherence to the rules in all situations.

I was once mandated by a state agency to redact the site location maps from a report, despite the fact that there is a public state historical marker on the side of the road at the site. The marker identifies the spot as the location of the site (a Spanish mission), and the marker info and site location is common knowledge and accessible on many online websites and smart phone apps. Duh!
column36: I don't necessarily think there needs to be principal added, but professional archeologists should never adopt a hardline approach to dealing with artifact collectors. And we shouldn't lump all artifact collectors into the "looter" category and condemn them all. In Texas, the "Pay to Dig" crises does not involve illegal excavations. This is being done with landowner consent and often by the landowners themselves. By lumping everyone into the looter category (which should be reserved for those who dig illegally) and condemning them, we further polarize the situation and lose out on opportunities to work with artifact collectors in meaningful ways.

The ridiculous notion that many academic archaeologists still see themselves as somehow superior to CRM archaeologists. 

As a  CRM archaeologist working in an academic setting for thirty-five years, I not only have the academic credentials that my faculty colleagues have, but I also an expert in construction principles and impact planning, environmental law, macro-budgeting, collections management (which most archaeologists are NOT trained to deal with), and large-scale personnel and project management. And, I am HAZMAT trained to respond to archaeological situations that are potentially unsafe.

column20: In general, the idea of intellectual property is similar today as it was in the mid-90s. Yet, there are numerous additional institutions (university, govt, federal agencies, private funders) at play today with complex rules about property rights. As always, this differs whether conducting work in the US or elsewhere. importantly, this principle does not take into account the rights of stakeholders -- especially community members of the lands directly affected -- or the different types of datasets that are common today. Enormous datasets generated from traditional fieldwork and remote sensing may have different codes regarding intellectual property.

column10:
1) Sharing knowledge between archeologist and indigenous or descendent communities - power sharing and knowledge transfer. Community based practice and a fair hearing for the voices that are muted or ignored in archeological discourse. 


2) The intersection of vandalism, looting, conflict, and the antiquities trade. 

3) Responsible collecting and curation practices; sustainability of collections.
column12: This principle is foundational to archeological practice, and is a much better formulation of the hackneyed adage "archeology is a destructive science". Archaeology and archeological fieldwork is a part of a system that, when it is functioning, produces knowledge.
column14: I very much agree with the spirit of this principle. However, it may be worth saying that the degree of consultation should be scaled to the level of effort of the project. A multi-year data recovery project on a national historic landmark should, for instance, involve more consultation than a small phase I project. It doesn't make sense to consult a lot and then not do very much work.
column18: Public support is critical to the continued existence of the discipline, particularly in the public sector.  Without a public constituency for archeological work, we won't exist. However, there is a crisis of expertise at the moment - pseudoarchaeology is pervasive, and the interpretation of archeological evidence by unqualified individuals has led and continues to lead to the production of misleading, damaging, or irresponsible narratives. Archeologists need to be able to share knowledge in a way that avoids outlandish, unsupportable, and/or racist theories about the past.
column20:
The beginning of this principle is too vague, applying to "knowledge and documents" while the end seems very specific - making prescriptions for how a hypothetical researcher might access specific information. It needs to be reworked so that it makes a bit more sense.

In addition, legal restrictions and countervailing interests should not be dismissed. Information on site locations, for instance, is especially sensitive, both from a legal standpoint, and from the point of view of tribes and other community members who may object to the sharing of particular information. In addition, researchers need to be able to safeguard sensitive information if they are granted access to it.
column26: I really don't agree that, when correctly done, archeology is destructive. It makes more sense to view archeology as producing knowledge from a raw material than it does to call it destructive. I support the general idea that archeologist should be adequately trained.
column28: Something about actively improving representation of diverse groups in the industry could be added to this principle.
column36: Prevention of vandalism and looting. Protections of sites in conflict zones. Combatting irresponsible interpretations of the archeological record, including anti-racism and anti-facism.

column14: We have an obligation to collaborate with affected groups and ensure that they are involved in every step of the decision-making process. Oral histories or other knowledge/skillsets brought by descendant communities are essential to interpreting and. understanding the past. We need to go beyond simply minimizing damage to actively building partnerships.
column18: I don't have serious issues with the wording of this particular statement. However, I think that we as a group have failed to adequately educate the public about archaeology. While this statement is well-meaning, I think it could be revised to communicate the urgent need for public engagement. Most people have no idea what we do or why archaeology matters. Our inability to communicate the importance of our field is already causing serious problems in terms of recruiting top students to major in the field, secure funding, etc.
column20: I think this could go further. We have an obligation to make data available to the public and any descendant communities we work with.
column28: The SAA really should have better guidelines and recommendations for creating and maintaining safe working environments. The laws of our home nation and rules of our institution are part of this, but I think this should be more specific. We need to make it clear to students or people in relatively more marginal positions that they can and should report harassment and discrimination. Supervisors, especially in field settings, should have systems for reporting harassment and discrimination in place. These reporting systems should include explicit directions for how to report supervisors. Any participants in these projects should know how to report this before they begin work on the project.

column10:
As someone who works in CRM,  the "race to the bottom" has been my primary concern. Firms low-balling bids to get work and then not having the proper funds to complete the work to standards so they don't. We don't see the local, state, or federal agencies holding these firms to the standards and calling them out for blatantly not meeting them. It is devastating to see the poor work from these firms allowing the destruction of important cultural resources. It is frustrating to watch sites that we have recorded and know will be significant given to these firms, who charge half the cost, for further study and immediately deem these sites insignificant to please the client. And it is even more frustrating that these same companies become a joke among other firms for the poor quality of their work, and yet agencies, at all levels, continue to do nothing. 
Exacerbating this situation is the lack of funding in general that pushes the field to use volunteers to do what should be considered skilled tasks. And while I love and sincerely appreciate the work that volunteers do and realize that some will come to know more than many trained professionals, that is the exception. We devalue our education, training, and expertise when we use volunteers to do a majority of the work because we are not given funding. And we encourage continued under funding by promising we can find volunteers to do the same work for free. 
The lack of funding and use of volunteers also means that field techs can be treated as disposable...people to be worked until they break for low pay, temporary employment, and no benefits. All of these issues contribute to the continued "race to the bottom" that does a disservice to our entire field by eroding the trust of the clients who wonder why one firm can do what they see as the same work for much less and with better result (no further work needed); the agencies, with whom we must negotiate the least amount of work for the least amount of money for those clients; and the public, who expects us to protect cultural resources.

column16: I would note that there is a challenge to acting on this principle in that it is often the case that important sites/collections are found and owned by private individuals.  Such sites and collections can include important archaeological information that, if not researched, will be lost to the profession.  It is true that by doing such research archaeologists may provide information that "enhances the commercial value" of a collection.  However, since the development of the ethics principles in 1996, the internet has created and sustained a large commercial marketplace, so it's not necessarily the case that archaeological research contributes to the enhancement of commercial value.  I believe that our challenge is to adhere to Principle 1, Stewardship, while doing our best to inform private individuals about what we see as the importance of sharing information about their objects with the profession and the public, while not contributing to the commercialization of archaeological objects or sites.  Discussions with these individuals about donating their collections and records to public repositories can produce the desired outcome.  However, for some parts of the archaeological record in North America, amateurs/private citizens find and hold the lion's share of sites and objects.  To ignore this is, in my opinion, short-sighted and impoverishes our knowledge of the past.  I would prefer to see this principle rewritten to take a more nuanced stance on working with privately-held collections while retaining the language about not inadvertently contributing to the commercialization of archaeological objects.

column10:
1) Museums and other collections that have no ethics policies, or policies that allow great freedom in deaccession decision making.

2) Repatriation--the SAA survey a few years ago showed that most SAA members thought that repatriation was good, but were generally unfamiliar with NAGPRA or the mechanics of international repatriation. Also, institutions that have maintained a retentive philosophy regarding NAGPRA collections.

3) Site vandalism and looting, and the exchange of stolen objects, especially in recovery of objects stolen from sites or museums where the legal ownership is hazy in some way.

4) Publication of articles and books that may reveal special Native American knowledge or practices without consultation with appropriate tribes.

5) Sexual harassment and discrimination, especially in field school situations.

column10:
When consultants in archaeological resource protection cases provide legal testimony on behalf of those charged with destroying our heritage. These "experts" are most often not experienced or knowledgeable about the regional archaeology, but nevertheless feel qualified to moderate its destruction, or assist in its looting.

When academics fail to abide fully with the terms of their federal permits. I am aware of several collections being held illegally in garages for decades. Reports from multiple year excavations from field schools never being submitted to the land managing agency. The propriety sequestering of data from public lands for the exclusive use of one university, while refusing to provide that data to actual owner. Widespread sharing of data owned by the federal government and protected against unauthorized release. The posting of site location information and confidential reports in publicly accessible online forums.

column10: Working to ensure the conservation and wise use of the archaeological record through legal protections.  Ensuring that collections and their associated records are maintained in such a way as to maximize their accessibility and utility for future research long term. Providing quality information to the public about the results of previous and ongoing archaeological work -- In the end, they are paying for it; what are they getting in return?  Being sensitive to the concerns and interests of local communities and descendant communities when designing archaeological research and fieldwork.
column28: Certainly we all want all students, employees, and colleagues to be spared from a hostile work environment.  As a woman who came up through the ranks in archaeology decades ago when sexual harassment was commonly encountered, though, I worry a bit about the direction that this is taking today within SAA and academia.  Back then, we had to fight our own battles, stand up for ourselves, and demand respect.  There were plenty of good men who treated us appropriately and backed us up when we stood up for ourselves.  But, generally speaking, nobody was responsible for "ensuring" that we were treated with respect except ourselves.  Physical safety is critically important and it's everybody's job. I'm not sure that bringing up students to expect that some entity -- their university, their employer, their professional organization -- bears all the responsible for ensuring that they feel safe and protected and respected is doing them a favor.  Personal responsibility is also important.  It's good practice for life in the world, and sometimes the best approach to a hostile work environment is a little hostility of your own.  Feel free to say "OK, Boomer" now.
column30: Generally speaking, yes.  But I believe strongly that archaeology is, at its core, a scientific discipline, and I worry about the trend that privileges other considerations at the expense of doing good science.
column32: Again, with the same caveat about the trend toward privileging other considerations over the requirements of doing good science.
column36: Are we still a scientific discipline or are we not?

column12: There needs to be qualification re public access to some of the information. Indigenous groups have sacred and spiritual information that, while it needs to be protected and should not be disseminated. The SAA Code of Ethics should acknowledge this, consult with relevant entities, and respect their wishes.
column14: Again, there are times when information about sites or artifacts have a spiritual or ritual significance, and the needs and wishes of the parties whose culture and beliefs are reflected in those sites and artifacts should have priority over other parties desires. SO, the idea of "beneficial to all parties involved" needs to be clarified and carefully considered.
column16: This is a serious problem that some of our colleagues in major museums like the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Chicago Art Institute do not seem to understand. Trafficking in antiquities from war-torn countries and impoverished localities is a significant problem. Publishing, exhibiting, and purchasing such collections is ethically problematic.
column20:
The idea that sites or collections "belong" to an individual must stop. As in many of the sciences, a researcher should have sole access for a period of time in which to study and publish the material. But after that, it should be accessible to other researchers. The qualification on that is that some materials should not be generally accessible if for cultural reasons they should not be widely studied and published (sacred materials, for instance).

Entities charged with protection of sites should determine who has permission to explore sites, this should not be the decision by the person who discovered the site.
column22: This needs qualification. For instance, researchers starting otu their careers may need to  publish in peer reviewed journals to gain jobs and tenure. They should not be put in the position of spending lots of time disseminating information to the pubic --until the academy changes its practices. Also, as noted in response to other items in this survey, culturally sensitive information might not be appropriate for general distribution and the code of ethics must acknowledge this.
column28: This varies greatly. There are, unfortunately, still pockets where sexual harassment is rampant. Also, our academy is not encouraging of as diverse a population of young people as it should. Why are there so few African American, Latinx, and Native American archaeologists? Clearly, those of us in the profession are doing an inadequate job of recruiting and retaining them and makingn sure that they are comfortable in our classrooms and on our excavations.
column34: Archaeology texts for undergraduates are doing a better job of including women in prehistory and in the profession, but we have done a dismal job of attracting minorities to our profession. Indeed, many groups look upon us with disapproval or suspicion. Also, we have not done a good job of engaging with some of our colleagues in the museum world about the ethics of collection acquisitions and consultations.

column12:
Stewardships is still vitally important, but it seems like this could be  more specific-- for example, mentioning climate change. Since I study coastal archaeology sites, I am keenly aware of the threats to these sites. 

Also seems a bit vague in talking about the "public" but not mentioning indigenous people specifically. This might be okay, but I don't think it should be first. I would prioritize indigenous rights before stewardship (in terms of the order of the principles).
column14: This spirit of this principle is SO important. But, the wording could be improved. "Consult actively with affects groups" sounds like archaeologist are still in charge.

column32: Need more about indigenous peoples of the Americas. Why aren't burials mentioned specifically? Too political in 1996? There should be some discussion of respect for anyone working with human remains.
column34: In academia there might also be issues with professors publishing research done by their students... Not sure it makes sense to make very specific guidelines that are only applicable to those working in one sector.
column36:
I feel like there is probably something missing, but I am not sure what off the top of my head!  Respect and communication could be stressed more throughout. More de-colonial language would be good.

I think the opinions of those archaeologists who are closer to the start of their careers and who may be from diverse racial groups/ethnicities should be prioritized. I am a 47 year old white woman. I think at this stage in the SAA it is more important to hear from younger people from different backgrounds. Not people like me (which is why I am not filling out the form for follow up conversations!).

I have read many of the other codes that are more specific in terms of standards of practice. I find them somewhat overwhelming. I personally find having 9 (or 10) more general and concise aspirational principles to be more helpful.  I think standards of practice would be hard for this organization with such a diverse membership.

That said, I would not object to more of a living document or ethical document with examples, as long as it was accompanied by a set statement on ethics.

column10:
1) The duty of archaeologists as public educators - especially when it comes to how to encourage stewardship
2) The interactions between archaeologists and "collectors"
3) (Here in the West) artifacts and sites between 50 - 100 years old aren't approached with the same anthropological concern as prehistoric sites are. My concern here is that archaeologists are privileging some histories and cultures through CRM.
column14: "Consult actively" can be strengthened. I would like to see the SAA explicitly support collaboration.
column16: It's still so thorny about how we engage with the people who collect these things, and not just the things themselves! Here in Utah we have adult children of "collectors" who feel (perhaps rightly) that throwing artifacts away is the best course of action they can take to retire the collections of their parents and grandparents.
column22: There are a lot of laws in place that apply to disclosing the nature and location of archaeological sites/resources, might be worthwhile to acknowledge that there are legal concerns that may inform how this principle gets implemented.
column24: This principle doesn't move me as much as some others... it seems like it has blinders on about the "curation crisis." Yes, archaeologists should support the continued use of previous records/reports/collections, but what is our responsibility for accessioning and de-accessioning things?
column28:
That first sentence misses the point, it focuses this whole principle on "training the next generation of archaeologists" instead of being decent people to everyone, all the time. 

"Archaeologists value and respect human lives and bodies" would be a better framing sentence. The explain the whys and hows of that value/respect.

This feels so wishy-washy about the actual problem: I've been sexually assaulted by archaeologists at conferences. I've been sexually harassed on the job site. I've confronted people who were engaged in sexually assaulting students while on field schools. Quite honestly, roll for "type of inexcusable conduct" and "place where you'll find archaeologists" and I can guarantee I've live it or can direct you to someone who can. Not all archaeologists are guilty of sexual misconduct and harassment, but *no* archaeologist is safe from it until *every* archaeologist loudly and constantly denounces it.

So be clear: SAA archaeologists value and respect human lives, experiences, and bodies. SAA archaeologists will not engage in behaviors or speech that devalue and disrespect human lives, experiences, and bodies. SAA archaeologists will strive to keep open and clear communication with each other on how best to foster environments that are not only safe, but thriving.
column30:
DIVERSITY??? Do we not have a commitment to improving access to archaeological education (and degrees and jobs) for people of diverse backgrounds?

What about some sort of reparations for all the gross stuff archaeologists used to do? Let's own that past and engage with stakeholders about how we can right some old wrongs.

The Principles start off strong, and they're heading in the right direction, but we're awfully far behind when it comes to supporting people of color and keeping sexual harassment under control.
column32:
- The Principles need to be backed up by the SAA (e.g. help archaeologists engage the public somehow)
- The Principle 9 misses the mark
- How can the Principles be complete if we don't acknowledge that we are a predominantly white scholastic body studying (most often) communities and people of color?
- Archaeologists should be nudged toward meaningful collaborations, not just "consultation." The law handles consultation in many cases, we need to strive to be better.
column34: I'm a government employee (Public Archaeologist, State of Utah).  I need to be able to show stakeholder communities that I engage with where my ethics lie, and trotting out these principles would not persuade anyone to think I'm on their side.
column36:
- Diversity is necessary (and currently lacking) and the Principles should loudly support it
- Sexual harassment and assault is rampant and the Principles should loudly denounce it and provide a framework for thriving environments
- No one's archaeology is "better than." Historical archaeology, even when it's a recent history, needs to be taken seriously.

column9: American Academy of Forensic Science, because I'm a forensic archaeologist, and the code for the American Board of Forensic Anthropology (which I helped rewrite as a member of the Board of Directors). Also international codes of ethics for mass graves, such as those put out by ICMP.
column10: I think it's twofold. I have concerns about some practitioners, specifically with regards to poor recordkeeping and poor/no data dissemination, but also with avocational archaeologists, looters, etc. destroying the archaeological record.  Both are damaging but in different ways.
column12: would prefer the statement regarding public understanding and long-term preservation was stronger (perhaps "must" instead of "should").
column20: I agree with the sentiment but I think that first sentence is a bit odd and doesn't clearly . Intellectual property is part of the archaeological record?  Why not just say "documents pertaining to and created during archaeological study, including but not limited to those pertaining to field recovery methods, location, conservation, or analysis of artifacts, features, and structures, are part of the archaeological record? That would also encapsulate the lab analysis part of things, which I don't think is clearly articulated here.
column22: I mean...sure, that would be ideal if every archaeologist presented or published their findings in ways that are accessible to the general public, but I think that's aspirational rather than realistic. Who has time to do that for every project? Literally no one that I know. I like the sentiment but I think this should not be presented as a mandate (perhaps "should" instead of "must"). I would also suggest taking the "reasonable time" thing out of this paragraph. I think it's covered earlier in a more appropriate place, and I think if you expect professionals to make their results available in easily digestible formats for the general public, you need to ease off of the time restriction. Formal publications are always going to take precedence, as they should, over popular articles or presentations. General public knowledge dissemination is imperative, absolutely--but it has to be at a lower priority than publishing in professional arenas where all of the relevant knowledge can be accessed ASAP.
column24:
There's a syntax error in this sentence that I can't quite untangle.  

"...they should encourage colleagues, students, and others to make responsible use of...increasing the care and attention given to that portion of the archaeological record..."?  This doesn't make sense grammatically.

Or is it:

"...they should encourage colleagues, students, and others to make responsible use of collections, records, and reports in their research as one means of...increasing the care and attention given to that portion of the archaeological record..."?  This is grammatically correct but doesn't make sense because it says "one means" but lists two. (Also, take out the comma before "and of increasing the care."
column28: Why does this say home nations? Shouldn't we also know the laws in the countries in which we work? I mean, if sexual assault is punishable by death in a particular country, it would behoove the field supervisor to know that since it could certainly cause issues if someone was raped at a field school and reported it to the local police. If our home country's laws are more stringent, then of course those should be followed.  I'd also like to see this section have a mandate to report assaults and harassment as mandated by local and institutional law and to hold supervisors responsible for making sure all students and trainees know the policies and laws and how to report them (point of contact, phone numbers, email addresses, physical addresses) and how to get other types of assistance (e.g., medical).
column30: Could use some additional work, but it's a good start.
column32: I don't actually recall reading anything about compliance with local, state, federal, and international laws and regulations pertaining to permits, operations, safety, reporting of results...for example, there are a fair number of countries, at least in Europe, where there are very strict permitting, data collection, training, education, and reporting requirements. As a specific example, Austrian laws say that only an archaeologist who is registered with the federal government may lead archaeological activities in that country, that all data must be collected in a particular way and submitted using particular electronic formats, and that all final reports must be written in German. This code should let folks know they're on the hook for knowing those and complying.
column34: No.  Needs stronger sexual assault/harassment language and more on compliance with local/state/federal laws and regulations.
column36: See previous comments re: host nation laws (both in terms of archaeological work and sexual assault and harassment).
column42: Separate Principles of Ethics and Standards of Practice,Ethical document(s) that provides examples
column43: Living document makes it sound like the principles can be changed willy-nilly, which should never be the case. Any changes should have to go through the Board and the membership. A platform for responding to real-life dilemmas sounds good, though. Separate principles and standards would be ideal, because one addresses ethical principles and the other deals with minimum standards of performing the work.  I would add the caveat that one of the ethical principles should be that members must abide by the standards of practice.

column9: In addition to the SAA Principles, I also consider the AAA Statement on Ethics when making ethics decisions. I have also received several ethics trainings through my employer, which I refer to when professional and archaeological spheres overlap.
column10:
- Long delays between accumulation and publication of data in academic contexts.

- Inadequate data sharing and transparency in research methods (e.g. providing databases to back up published results).

- Lack of accountability for project directors, crew chiefs, professors, etc. who sexually harass, bully, and/or abuse subordinates in the context of archaeological work.

- Wage stagnation and general poor treatment of entry-level workers within the context of cultural resource management.

- Lack of transparency and accountability within the SAA itself.
column12: I think this principle is adequate in concept. It could stand to be more vigorously pursued.
column14: This principle is inadequate in modern archaeology. In its wording, it privileges the archaeologist and puts other stakeholders (e.g. indigenous communities) in second place. What if the archaeologist feels they have acted in good faith but a beneficial working relationship has not been established for all parties? Are they free to proceed in good ethical standing? The principle would seem to say yes. In my own practice we do not operate this way; we do not take what is not freely given. But I know that there are some archaeologists who act as if they are the arbiters of what is right in this regard and that have proceeded against the wishes of other stakeholders in their work.
column16: This principle is not strong enough. There are still some archaeologists who find excuses to work with looters and looted collections. More generally, members of the art collecting and museum world continue to defend looting in various mediums, including newspaper editorials, interviews, etc. Those who defend or allowed or enable looting should be shunned from archaeology. The SAA should state that looting is destruction of cultural heritage and will not be condoned in any manner.
column18: This principle is fine as written. It's poorly implemented in practice.
column20: Another one that too few archaeologists actually follow, and for which there is too little enforcement by journals. It should also be amended for the digital era; in addition to the knowledge and documents created through the study of archaeological resources, it should include those tools designed and created to effect that study, where relevant. For instance, the GIS analyses, statistical tools, scripts, code, etc. used to derive published results should be made available. This is already standard practice in many "hard" science fields, most notably biology. In a timely note, the COVID19 crisis has provided many examples where the required publication of supporting data showed that the research and conclusions coming from some sources was simply of poor quality or erroneous. It would be interesting indeed to have this degree of transparency in archaeological research publications.
column22: Again, a nice thought. Compliance and enforcement is laughable in the academic context, somewhat better in CRM. Perhaps defining "within a reasonable time" more clearly would be a good start. Tangentially, data might be more readily disseminated if the community were more open to the publication of negative results (a problem in all scientific publishing).
column24: Once again, this is adequate as a statement. In my own experience, perhaps 1/3 of archaeologists view collections as "theirs" and treat them accordingly, the other 2/3 more or less follow these guidelines. What recourse is there within the framework of the SAA for those 1/3? I have reported individuals who mishandled or destroyed collections materials to appropriate authorities (government, curators, etc.) and, in a collections role, have refused access to individuals who failed to exercise proper care in the past. But it never occurred to me to bring any of these incidents up with SAA because these are only principles, and the organization is completely toothless.
column26:
"...and they must make the utmost effort to deploy those resources to the fullest extent possible during the course of said research; to do otherwise is a dereliction of professional responsibility."

It is not enough to have materials on hand; one must use them. I could provide numerous examples, especially in CRM contexts, where archaeologists declined to use the full resources available to them to do good archaeology, because it was easier/faster/cheaper to do a subpar job. Anyone involved in CRM can name at least one group in their region that commonly operates in this manner; these organizations should be held to account.
column28:
Again, this is a nice idea. We can all think of many examples within the discipline where it is not followed in practice. What is the consequence, in the context of the SAA, for violating this principle? 

Perhaps this (and the previous 8 principles) should be amended to state that those who are aware of such activity on the part of others and tolerate it or fail to speak out, are also complicit. In my own research area, it is common knowledge which project directors commit sexual harassment, bully their graduate students, ignore student and worker safety, and so on. Some people are honest about it but others prefer to remain silent, or pretend the problem does not exist.
column30:
- Lack of sufficient duty of care in most points.

- Lack of consequences.

- Outdated in regards to technical advancements.

- Inadequate for archaeology as a profession. I recognize that there are many non-professional archaeologists involved in the SAA; perhaps we need separate codes of ethics. I recognize that the RPA exists; nobody I know cares about them (and in fact I have had multiple archaeologists tell me they regard the RPA as a joke). The SAA is the premiere archaeological organization in the Americas and it needs to take ownership of standards of conduct and practice for archaeology accordingly.
column32: Again, no duty of care and no consequences. These are not standards, they are guidelines. There are a fair number of archaeologists who do a poor job of following them, or flagrantly disregard them. Since there is no mechanism for compliance, reporting, or enforcement, they are just nice suggestions. That is a legitimate way to approach things, but then the SAA can't pretend to be the voice and representative of responsible archaeology. For instance, why should I take seriously the SAA efforts to lobby the US Congress regarding cultural heritage when the organization can't hold its own members to account in terms of protecting the same resources, not working with looters or looted collections, etc.?
column34: I work in both academia and CRM. See previous comments for why I think the SAA principles are inadequate in both sectors.
column36: I think most of the relevant ethical issues could be addressed by modifying/enforcing the existing principles along the lines previously discussed. Nothing comes immediately to mind that would require a 10th, separate point.

column10:
Treatment of and engagement with local communities, especially indigenous and marginalized ones.
Promotion of inclusivity and diversity.
column12: "All people" is a bit of an aspirational over-reach perhaps, much like "world heritage" or "public good" that often accompanies this kind of language.
column14: "Affected groups" might not be specific enough and doesn't offer grounds for making a decision about which groups might have priority. "Affected" is pretty vague.
column18: Fine in some way, but in complete. An organization built largely on the archaeological record of Indigenous peoples of the Americas should have a clearer, more precise acknowledgement of them as a priority community. Also, this principle still sees archaeologists as the ones who provide knowledge to groups rather than welcomes legitimate input from those same groups. A little too much outreach rather than possible collaborations or "inreach."
column28: Very important newer principle, but I would like to see some adjustment beyond "home nation" or "institutional workplace." We also have certain community standards for those archaeologists might work with, including Indigenous communities, that might need careful attention. Also, the "this includes" language is all about very well-defined negative outcomes -- especially legal ones -- like harassment or assault, which is absolutely necessary, but some language about making the field more diverse and welcoming from a non-legal perspective could be added.

column12: The first two sentences of Principle 1: Stewardship still hold true. However the second two sentences imply that archaeologists and archaeology are or should be the final arbitrator of this without question. In recent times more voices and collaboration is going into decisions on how this stewardship is managed.
column14: This has become much more complex than the assumptions under which Principle 2: Accountability was written. Many of the voices, public, descendant community, property owner, government agency, project developer, are highly competing on this topic.Being beneficial to all affected groups is not always possible, and often reflects regulatory limits for deferring to archaeological or descendants' concerns over economic or similar concerns.
column16: The focus and approach, including phrasing of issues, in Principle 3: Commercialization are way out of date. While the commercialization and exploitation of archaeological objects is a problem, as is their destruction willful or otherwise, this needs to not just replace commercial value with archaeological scientific value. It needs to consider the importance of not only the objects but the treatment of these materials to the communities from which they arrive, especially descendant communities, cultures, or nations--put the cultural and heritage value back in it.
column18: Again the focus and phrasing of Principle 4: Public Outreach and Education is out of date and out of focus for current concerns. This again sets archaeologists at the pinnacle of control of the archaeological record, dictating to "publics" about what is important about the record and how that record should be treated. This should be collaborative and archaeologists should answer to and not just speak at concerned peoples, especially descendant communities and local communities of which the archaeologists are usually not members. This like many of the other principles sets archaeologists, as "professionals" above the "public" as the essentially the uniformed who need to be informed. This needs to be better balanced with the principle on archaeologists being responsible to affected peoples.
column20: Principle 5: Intellectual Property largely holds true today, however, does not well or directly address the related problems of protecting irreplaceable archeological resources from harm at the same time of making information available more for everyone and not simply for an insular group of archaeological researchers. Too much focus on information for archaeologists and not others or nonprofessionals concerned with cultural heritage. Also this does not consider the concern from descendant peoples or cultural groups of how the information of their heritage and ancestors is characterized, used, or distributed, or may be proprietary to or protected by them.
column22: Principle 6: Public Reporting and Public Reporting addresses many of the short comings of Principle 5 for making information popularly available. However, Principle 6 still does not directly address the issue of working with descendant peoples and cultural groups about the appropriate presentation of information that may be sensitive to them. This Principle once again sets the archaeologist as the ultimate purveyor of archaeological truth, without acknowledgement of the possible involvement of others directly in the decision making.
column24: Principle 7 holds true but should recognize and encourage the involvement of affected peoples and descendant communities more.
column26: Principle 8 holds true, but might emphasize the consideration of non-destructive techniques more.
column28: Relying only on the law is not good enough. Most workplaces are able to set up policies that go above and beyond the law without coming into conflict with the law, and can use these internally set polices as grounds for dismissal. SAA could do the same, set a better bar.
column30: See notes regarding the principles. Archaeology is less about archaeologist gathering knowledge and enlightening or professing to external ignorant masses, and more about involving multiple voices, perspectives, and the people who provide them, especially those of descendant communities or communities where the archaeological sites are located (and where the archaeologists often are not from).

column43: I think a unifying code, set of principles or standards is important. A living document is difficult to keep abreast of; I don't follow AAA's. Having documents across sector's or regions will also be difficult to track for those of us who work widely across regions and sectors; a unified approach or at least capping approach is needed. If an approach for ethical documents that provide examples is decided upon, a living document will be needed because those examples risk quickly becoming stale, just like the existing Principles have. The code needs to remain aspirational because the current real world situation for practicing archaeologists do not permit the full ideals of even the current Principles to be fully met in practice, but we should still strive for full attainment. Finally, especially if examples are used, at no point should morals be confused with ethics.

column10:
It's hard to limit myself to on primary ethical concern, so I've listed my top concerns in no particular order:

Accessibility: It has become evident to me that archaeology is not always accessible to a variety of stakeholder, particular indigenous and historically marginalized groups, to low-income students, and people with disabilities. I have a lower middle class background and while I was able to pay for my fieldschool, it was a financial burden. This seems to be the case for many, and there are many others who would like to pursue fieldschools but can't due to the cost. I think there needs to be a concerted effort to fund training for individuals interested in archaeology but can't afford the costs associated with traditional archaeological fieldschools/training.

Safe working environment: After last year's SAA meetings, the recent story about the Harvard Anthropology department, and numerous other examples it has become widely known that there is an issue of sexual harassment and abuse within archaeology. I do think this is changing as more people have become aware of it, but this seems to be a long-standing issue in archaeology, tied particularly to the hierarchical power structure of academia and field research. 

Merging engagement and scientific research: I personally see archaeology as a scientific endeavor. However, this does not mean that I think archaeology is apolitical, or mutually exclusive from collaborative/engaged archaeology and working with native communities. However, there seems to be rift developing where archaeologists either have to be fully immersed and dedicated to engagement, or objective scientists that do have little to no interaction with native groups. I do not think there needs to be such a stark divide. This pertains especially to ancient DNA. I think it is possible to conduct ancient DNA studies that are both scientifically grounded and meet ethical standards for working with human remains
column22: I am an advocate for open science, so I personally think there needs to be more emphasis here on making archaeological data and knowledge public within a reasonable amount of time. I think it's perfectly acceptable for archaeologists to keep information private prior to publication. However, once published data should be made as accessible as possible. Archaeologists also need to publish or share their data in reasonable time frame! It is unacceptable to keep research unpublished for 10 years (or more), as we all know horror stories of sites not being reported, artifacts lost, etc.
column28: I think this statement could be stronger. As I mentioned in my primary ethical concerns about the field response, it is clear that feeling safe in the field, office, lab, etc. is an issue for many (especially women). Abusers/harassers need to face tangible consequences.

column20: As a student, I experienced numerous scholars keeping records and reports as their own and would not give me access to them. I also had a scholar tell me that I was their stealing research since they wrote one report on the subject in 2007 but I was writing my thesis in 2015 and was elaborating on their research and giving them credit throughout. I believe an emphasis should be placed on scholars releasing their reports within a given time period and that it is unethical to allow scholars to view unpublished work when they request it. I also believe that there should be a bigger emphasis placed on the section about archaeological documents & reports are part of the archaeological record and should not be viewed as a personal possession.

SAA members MUST abide by these laws and ensure that the work and educational settings in which they have responsible roles as supervisors are conducted. Violations of these laws will result in the permanent revoke of an SAA membership. 

There is a large amount of violators who are never prosecuted by their universities, place of work, or by the law. Please consider creating an independent organization that will review complaints and revoke memberships of people who the organization finds to have credible violations regardless of whether they were prosecuted by their place of work or by they law.

column34: Much of the archaeological work that I have done has been within the forensic domain in the recovery of human remains and associated evidence. In this domain, there are no real safeguards protecting archaeological heritage and it is up to those who occupy these jobs (forensic anthropologist/archaeologist) to work with local and state historical commissions to ensure that materials are transferred to the proper person if they have prehistoric or historic value. This type of material can fall through the cracks and get stored or discarded if people are not paying attention.
column36: It is difficult to anticipate unique situations that may be faced by archaeologists, but in the previous question I spoke about he ethical responsibility of placing items found in the hands of the historical commissions instead of police or medical examiners offices. This really refers to using one's archaeological knowledge in such a way as to assist with this type of troubleshooting and also intervening when a wrong is seen or experience. In other words taking the initiative to ensure stewardship and brokering that the material gets to the right agency.

column10: There are many, but in my field (Mesoamerican archaeology) we are very interested in decolonization and providing more access to those traditionally shut out of the academic community. A lot of the conversations have focused on finding a way for the people in the areas in which we work have access to research and to have access to archaeological training if they wish to become become researchers and conduct field work. Also something on our mind is repatriation of looted objects, as well as preventing the art market from fueling further looting (which can end up funding violence and political corruption in our regions as well). Also an important ethical concern is continuing to make our field safer for women and people of color - in the field, in conferences, in the classroom.

column9: I primarily consult the World Archaeological Congress Codes of Ethics and statements. I have also consulted the Register of Professional Archaeologists codes of conduct but do not choose to register. I do not use the RPA or SAA as guideposts for my own practice, and have not in the past, only as a reference point comparing organizations to one another in terms of their values.
column10: Recognizing and behaving thoughtfully with respect to the consequences of our work on living people should be very high on the list of ethical concerns for archaeologists. I also believe that we have obligations to our students, colleagues, and the archaeological record, but that those obligations have long overshadowed the sociopolitical context of archaeology in the present. A research project that is well-researched, excavated properly, documented, published, and archived can nonetheless be carried out in a way that avoidably fuels political unrest, endangers local residents, or harms Indigenous descendant communities.
column16: It seems strange that this principle proposes a course of action whereas the other principle, about responsibility to communities, does not. I think this needs to be copy edited or all the principles should include a succinct list of potential courses of action. The truth is that every single principle requires that we weigh potential effects of our work on different stakeholders so I do not think that the framing of the second half of this principle is particularly helpful.
column18: This is difficult to understand and lacks the succinctness that memorable codes of ethics require. Still, I believe the sentiment is extremely important. I think we need to start this principle with a non-complex sentence such as: "Archaeologists should participate in public outreach and advocacy." then explain the complexities outlined here, in my opinion.
column20: Again I feel this buries the principle too deeply in the paragraph. This is also an important issue to address though.
column22: I believe it would be appropriate to note that this includes digital records and products. Many people do not consider their digital processes to be part of their archive, so to speak.
column24: I think I agree but I do not understand what the 2nd half of the last sentence means?
column26: I do not think this principle is framed well. Students need to be trained well regardless of whether a discipline is destructive. I think we should state that members have a duty to ensure that their trainees are prepared to conduct research and, if we must, only mention the destructive nature of the discipline as an additional reason this is an ethical imperative. Our duty to students is not dependent on that.
column28:
Again I believe the lede is buried here. We are ethically obligated to foster a supportive and safe environment in the research encounter, regardless of whether students are participating. It would be stronger to say that and then explain as this paragraph has done. That being said, this is much better than anything we have had up until this point and I commend the organization for this.

I also don't understand why racial category is not included in this list? It may not be a biological reality, but it is a social and legal reality, and has become more pertinent since this was written surely. Consider whether a different version of the concept of race or presumed race could be included here to show visible support for Black members & directly critique racial categorization (as opposed to ignoring it).
column30: I have found them altogether too focused on "service to each other as presumed academics" and not at all helpful in navigating the complicated ethical dilemmas we actually face. As an ethics bowl participant I definitely did not find the SAA principles provided me the tools to know how to move forward.
column32: I think it is a mistake that we do not acknowledge or name the extractive history of archaeology (and colonialism as a broader movement) anywhere in our principles. It would be appropriate to say "we must acknowledge the harms that have been inflicted in the process of building the field of American archaeology and commit to considering the role our work can have in contemporary peoples' lives".
column34: I work in an "alternative academic" job setting and the principles before now have seemed to assume a lot about what we do with our time. Many of us do not run projects or have students in the formal sense but would still like to be guided by our professional community's values.

column43: I do not think a blog is a useful form of "living document" but I suspect the organization has the resources to host an actual living document on their new website. It would be useful to hold a few check-in type forums (rather than uni-directional lectures to members) to check in with various portions of our community over time to facilitate rolling revisions. As our current process is, we have a very narrow and temporally specific snapshot.

column12: Although I understand and generally agree with this principle, it universalizes heritage such that it appears of equal value to all peoples, which is a very western, scientific perspective. The difficulty is that descendant communities have stronger ties to their archaeological record than everyone else and should have more say in its disposition, and this overlooks this issue. I am not sure how it could be easily resolved within the confines of this principle.
column20: Please note that federal agencies actively contest and operate against this principle. As part of their permitting stipulations, they make clear that they own any data and reports resulting from work on federal lands. Although their position itself is a violation of ARPA, it is current federal practice.
column22: See previous comment; federal agencies contest this principle.
column30: With the exception of #1, the principles focus on archaeology as a research profession, even though 80 - 90% of US archaeologists now work in CRM. There are a number of international statements concerning ethical best practices for heritage management and conservation (e.g., the ICOMOS Burra Charter). The SAA principles should at least have some aspects of these rolled in, to get this list into the 21st century.

The near absence of heritage management concerns in our current principles reflects historical onesidedness and needs to be brought to the fore.

column10: Determination of artifact ownership for abandoned or neglected collections and explicitly emphasizing the importance of maintaining digital records.
column20: As a collections manager, unsupervised researcher access is a double-edged sword. Research on legacy collections is exactly why those collections exist. However, many simply do not have the attention to detail required to maintain a sort of “chain of evidence” required to piece together legacy collections. Accessing original collections is great—but not to permanently alter documentation and artifact records that can never be reversed or retraced. There should also be more emphasis on “materials and documents available to others” INCLUDING digital records, reports, and other scientific calculations.
column22: This principle is probably the most challenging of them all. Obviously, reporting is important. Publishing is great. But who is really graced with the amount of time to do this?? Tailoring reporting to all interested parties is incredibly time-consuming, and ultimately leads to halfhearted efforts that perpetuate the perception that archaeologists are ivory-tower types who hoard data. Public outreach is a special skill, and many do not have it. Is it maybe better that it’s done less frequently with greater quality vs. done frequently with poor results?
column24: There should be an explicit reference to digital records, which is becoming an ever greater challenge for collections managers.
column26: There could be an emphasis on continuing education in this principle. Many practices of the 60s are no longer pillars of archaeological research, and the field as a whole is suffering from outdated “best practices.” Continuous education is the only way to keep up with rapidly changing technological innovations.
column30: There are some areas that could use some updating to reflect modern working conditions, but as a whole the principles are accurate and relevant.
column34: There does need to be a greater emphasis on what comes after fieldwork. Collections management, artifact rehousing, working with legacy data, and converting early digital media into useable forms (the archaeology of our archaeology, if you will).
column42: I am satisfied with the format of the current Principles,An aspirational code
column43: Although living documents are able to reflect our rapidly evolving field, it seems like it would also leave more room for a small handful of people making decisions about specific issues. An actual set document (aspirational code)  is great because it’s a static place to refer back to and young professionals know what is expected from them right from the beginning.

column43:
The code of ethics is great but it should not be an "aspirational" code. Who is aspiring to uphold it? 

Having learned these codes as a student I thought archaeology had a very high standard of ethics. Throughout graduate school and my ensuing career, I have been continuously appalled by the "open secrets" of the unethical behavior of colleagues who blatantly defy this code. The lack of punishment or policing of the code points to hypocrisy, which individuals take upon themselves to correct by outing bad actors in public forums like we have seen in the SAAs before. While sexual harassment has rightfully been vilified, less public infractions such as the hoarding of data, nepotism in granting committees, and bad faith "community engagement" remains rampant.
