column10: In no specific order... 1) Equity, Discrimination, and Sexual Harassment, 2) fair pay, safe working conditions, and reasonable work hours for field technicians and field directors in CRM, and 3) lack of consultation or involvement of descendant communities by those conducting non-CRM archaeological research
column12: I feel this is a long standing principal that the majority of archaeologists adhere to today.  There are a few select firms or individuals who for work will underbid the effort they really need to adhere to this or are willing to check a clearance box and when doing that erode these principals.  They are a very small minority of firms.  In addition, there are too many who do research for research sake and destroy resources that could otherwise be preserved. Archaeological excavation should be focused on endangered resources, either at natural (erosion) or development loss risk. So this statement is still relevant and should be always forefront.
column14: This is unfortunately only a standard held high in CRM community and frequently ignored by the Academic one.  It is still rare today for any in Academic world to proactively consult with descendant communities or conduct outreach with public unless required to under law.  This statement needs to be tweaked to further push for more involvement with descendant communities and local populations by those conducting Academic research or research for research sake outside of a regulatory trigger.
column16: I'm not sure how any professional archaeological activity would enhance the sale of items?  And frankly, most of the items that have the most monetary "value" are those associated with burial context which are either "whole" or "ritual."  I think instead archaeologists need to focus on working WITH descendent communities to get to public the message WHY those resources should stay in situ.  And determine which items of "high monetary value" are currently on display in museums that should be considered for repatriation under NAGPRA, but are being held onto by museums because of the "object value," rather than "research value" attached to it. Further archaeologists should work to educate the public at large on why the artifact alone is lacking in significance to reduce the number of "buyers" an item may have, and partner WITH avocational archaeologists to teach them the value of research and data collection to at least diminish the destruction of that info and for them to act as educator advocates to others who may sell artifacts.
column18: But archaeologists need to do more then "tell" during public outreach, but need to "listen" and "learn" from that outreach and the descendent and local communities as well.
column20: Made available via a public repository and including "curation" budget for records of any research conducted.
column24: Few in academic world encourage M.A. and Ph.D. students to utilize existing collections, but instead force them to do "fresh excavations" far too often.  In addition, creative mitigation utilizing past excavated collections should be utilized when a site is inadvertently destroyed rather than further destruction by excavating another undisturbed and protected site, yet too many aim for "in kind" excavation instead of detailed new analysis on existing collections which could bring more value and be less destructive to the archaeological record.  In addition, archaeology on protected sites should be discouraged unless a portion has ongoing impacts from erosion or there is other concern for data loss over time.
column28: Should abide by MORE then laws.  This NEEDS to be updated.
column30:
Nowhere have you addressed that all field projects will adhere to at least the base OSHA level of safety and that every project will have a Safety Plan to ensure the safety of its employees.  In addition, archaeology is one of the worlds where a field tech may work 12-14 hour days, 6 days a week, for months on end with no break.  Those working conditions are not safe or in the best interest of the "expendable" technicians and SAA's code of ethics need to address it.  

No where in the SAA Principles of Ethics is consultation with descendent communities and at least listening to, if not adhering to, their concerns addressed.  This is a MAJOR problem with academic research today.

No where do you address equitable pay for any employees.  Arch techs are incredibly under paid and women still get paid far less than men.  Even a broad statement concerning treatment and fair practices in payment and employment should be included.
column32: See previous statement
column34: I was in CRM for 10 years, now in an Academic setting doing CRM.  Ethic statements addressing current ethical issues are lacking on both the CRM and Academic side

column10: Ensuring fair representation of women and minorities in archaeology; curbing harassment in research and contract archaeology; preventing destruction/exploitation of archaeological sites worldwide; ensuring that our profession is respectful of and constructively engages concerns of Native Americans, descendant communities, and other stakeholders.
column12: Ethical stewardship must necessarily involve descendant communities and other stakeholders. They are the rightful caretakers and advocates of the past. Archaeologists may facilitate and contribute to this process, but by no means do we have the monopoly on protection and interpretation of archaeological resources. This principle could use some rewording to emphasize that stewardship is by definition collaborative.
column14: I feel this principle is weak and comes across as perfunctory. It's not just about consulting actively and establishing working relationships, but of prioritizing the needs and wishes of descendant communities and stakeholders. There is a general level of public accountability because the archaeological level is irreplaceable, but there is also specific accountability to stakeholders tied to the individual histories of sites, regions, and communities.
column16: This principle statement glosses over the fact that many looted "art" objects are burial goods that are sacred or hold special importance to descendant communities and that their procurement has resulted -- and in many cases continues to result -- in the destruction and desecration of human burials. The SAA should take a stronger ethical stance against the study and publication of looted objects and should advocate for the repatriation of burial goods and other objects of indigenous cultural patrimony -- both privately held ones and those that are part of museum collections.
column18: This statement should be revised for the 21st Century. Descendant communities and other stakeholders are not simply passive "publics for archaeology" but rather should be given agency to participate or comment on archaeological research from the early project design stages to deciding whether and how they want results of research to be presented. Some descendant communities may not want archaeological data and interpretations to be made public, or may offer alternative interpretations. Archaeologists should be strongly encouraged to involve descendant communities and stakeholders in decision about public education and outreach, and to move away from the role of sole interpreters of the past to that of facilitators of multivocal exchanges about the past.
column22: This needs to include open access. Also, consent/involvement of descendant communities.
column30: They could use some updating.
column32: Input should be sought from members/stakeholders in countries outside the US, especially Latin America.
column36: We could use a statement on recognizing the colonial legacy of archaeology, especially in the Americas, and unequal international relations that continue to affect research in countries outside the US and Canada.

column10: Sharing information with the public, transparency, sexual harassment, illegal sales of artifacts, looting of sites, battling pseudoarchaeology and nonsense television programs, plagiarism, discrimination, equal opportunity and ending racism.
column12: Strongly agree stewardship is important, but also needs to consider value of living people over their records, that archaeology is not done to the detriment of the cultures we study, and done in the spirit of collaboration and partnership.  Also needs to recognize stewardship done in partnership with citizens or descendent communities, include them in the definition of who is doing archaeology and who is broadly responsible for stewardship.
column14: I like this one- needs to explicity state what is likely assumed under all levels of professional activity- that publication and dissemination of results is shared.
column16: I feel language can be stronger. Affiliation with terrorist groups and the law enforcement component is so important. So many advances have been made in archaeologists working with law enforcement, training in what to look for, long term participation in investigations that uncover small and large scale operations. "carefully weigh" changed to stronger language- don't do it, don't be part of it, don't encourage it. Essential to many of the television programs that archaeologists involved are not allowed or encouraged to participate as it violates their professional code of ethics.
column18: All archaeologists should undertake these activities. Supporting efforts of others is fine but a way many get out of doing it. Public benefit of archaeology should be done for all, by all. Advocacy is important, but scientific literacy, informing local decision making processes, impacting social issues through archaeology- more than just making a poster or brochure. And enlist public support for stewardship is great- but enlist the public as stewards, make more active, would strengthen this principle.
column20: I agree with the principle but it does not adequarly apply to intellectual property issues today.Just as it's listed there should be a compelling reason to restrict access, I hope it can be balanaced by a compelling or reasonable reason to request the data. We go down lots of rabbit holes to share, when there was no research question or proposal that laid out why the data was needed. It would be interesting to hear more on this topic as something aligned to best practices or case by case examples could show more what to consider. Where a living document might serve this principle better than aspirational.
column22: I strongly agree this is important but it does not apply to challenges today. Wide arrange of publications- that's certainly not the case. column28: SAA should not defer to the laws for ethical guidelines. In over 30 US states, you can use being frightened of same-sex sexual advances as a legal defense for harming or killing a queer person. American archaeologists work in nations all over the world that do not have equal protections for women, queer people, or certain religious groups. SAA should hold all members accountable for respecting all people and treating everyone equally and with respect. SAA should not tolerate racism, sexism, or any type of bigotry from any of its members regardless of the laws of the area, and deferring to legal and institutional rules as opposed to taking a strong stance on this is cowardly.

column12:
While the ideals of stewardship listed here are important, they also reinforce the idea that archaeologists know best/ know more than local descendant communities, particularly Native Americans.  

"Stewards are both caretakers of and advocates for the archaeological record for the benefit of all people;" - not all sites should be excavated or shared with all people.  The overarching "cultural heritage for all' argument discredits Native American knowledge and expertise. Burial sites should not be disturbed. Ancestral remains and funerary, sacred and patrimonial objects should be returned to the appropriate descendant community(ies).  

Archaeologists need to set up partnerships with descendant tribes - real partnerships, not just lip-service.  Archaeologists are not the only stewards of the past, and they need to acknowledge and lift up voices other than their own.
column14:
This needs to be a stronger statement about working with descendant communities from the beginning - the initial planning stage of a project.  Not at the end or a brief notification.

In addition, it is beyond frustrating to hear bioarchaeologists say, "well, I don't work in the US, so NAGPRA doesn't apply, and I don't know much about it." NAGPRA (repatriation, tribal involvement)  touches on a major ethical accountability foci within the field of archaeology, and needs to be a standard part of training, whether academic, CRM or amateur.
column16:
This is an important statement - but is something I was never taught in my studies of archaeology, from BA to MA to PHD.  I have never heard a colleague talk about a time when they did this (chose not to do a project because of commercial impact). I have heard many more stories, both in the US and abroad, where armed guards were hired to protect sites because of valuable objects (or rumors of valuable objects).  

While I agree with the statement, I am struggling with it, because it is something that I do not see practiced or discussed in the field.  How can the SAA, as the national organization, do more to support this ethical aspiration?
column18:
This is a highly problematic sentence:  "Many publics exist for archaeology including students and teachers; Native Americans and other ethnic, religious, and cultural groups who find in the archaeological record important aspects of their cultural heritage; lawmakers and government officials; reporters, journalists, and others involved in the media; and the general public." 

Archaeologists should not be "telling" a Native community their history.  They should be partnering with descendant communities to creative collaborative, community-based projects that benefit the community, not just the academic's career or a federal or state agency's project timeline.  

Public outreach should be an even more integral part of archaeology.  Why does it matter? Who are we helping?
column20:
I think there are more facets of intellectual property that need to be addressed here.
-Not all research should be public. This goes well beyond protected site location information. 
-Previously taken images of Native American human remains should not be shown or used in publications, yet they still are consistently, and often in ways that are completely unnecessary to prove the point of the publication. Similar issues exist with sacred objects.       

-Why are we supposed to continue citing the work of known sexual harassers in peer-reviewed publications?
column22: Again, more information than site information often should be protected.  In addition, with today's push towards open-access and digital archiving, when looking up a site, I can often find "protected" site information with a simple google search, which is quite disturbing - often from federal and state agency reports.
column24:
Again, this needs to be stronger.  There has been a curation crisis for decades - and yet there is still a big push to go excavate a new site to gain an academic degree, and a notable second-tier hierarchy for those who choose to do collections-based research. 

So. Many. repositories are unsustainable, and hold archaeological collections that do not meet modern archival standards of care.  And these same institutions that do not fund collections care often do not support repatriation, or do so grudgingly only because it is federal law.  It is honestly a disgrace to the field and to the profession.
column26: Again, this could be worded better.  The title does not quite match the statement. column43: Technically, all association principles and standards are living documents in that the association members can vote to have them, revise them, or do away with them at any time. The principles of ethics should continue to be aspirational and this is very important; we need to have ideals to reach towards. The principles of ethics and standards of practice should be two separate documents. The standards of practice should be more directive and include a code of conduct. It would be helpful to have examples and these should be available online to members as a living document that is updated relatively frequenly. Examples should describe the ethical dilemma, what principles and/or standards apply, how the situation was resolved, and what the results were (if known). It would be an interesting experiment to include a way for people to comment on the examples.

column10:
I'm not currently a practicing field archaeologist. From when I was 10+ years ago, I was aware of concerns with how archaeologists managed their work in response to pressures from developers (pressure being to not see things, not report them, not require monitors, and similar); how archaeologists respected and interacted with stakeholders and associated communities (appropriate consultation); and ensuring good documentation and curation of the sites we work on and materials we collect (particularly under strained budgets and pressures from developers). I expect these pressures still exist, but I can't speak to them directly.

Publication concerns such as plagiarism and appropriate use/purchase of publications for teaching are perennial, but have also taken new shapes in our more digital world. I wouldn't call them the major issues, but because they are essential to building both careers and trust within the profession, they should be called out for attention more often than they currently are.

Gender-based harassment and discrimination are major issue and ones I know the SAA has been/is struggling with. We need constant vigilance for these, and an ethical culture that creates equality (at minimum) for those who report having been harmed by them.

We are also living in an era of climate change and - as I type - a US that may finally be waking up to its centuries of racial inequality and discrimination. We should ensure that our ethical principles require clear and equal (at minimum) attention to communities and peoples whose voices have been muffled. While ethical principles should not prescribe research topics or products, archaeologists should ensure that our science is clear and accessible with respect to major issues facing society. It may also become an ethical issue to ensure that equitable portions of archaeological effort are divided between basic research and research that is applied to major issues facing society.
column18: Currently archaeological information is not well-integrated or used in the global response to climate change. While more analysis of the reasons for this are needed, part of the reason (from personal research in the issue) appears to be that archaeologists have ended their analyses at the point of archaeological understanding and NOT ensured that links are available from their research to climate issues facing society. They have left it to others to make the connections, which has resulted in archaeology being left out of most major climate assessments of the past 30 years. While this may feel scientifically safe, it has created a context in which archaeological sites and the information and connections they hold are not valued by the world at large, and by extension both sites and information are at greater risk of destruction by climate impacts and the global climate response lacks human time depth. Archaeologists must have responsibility to engage in major modern social issues.
column22: Recognition is growing that in situ preservation may not be possible in a growing number of places due to impacts of climate change. While I don't think this should change publication ethics, changes in the dangers to in situ materials due to climate change should be recognized somewhere.
column26: There's a piece missing here, which is funding for curation and write up. In the grants of which I have been a part, funding for the final stages of research were considered to be someone else's responsibility, not that of the research funders. This makes compliance with this ethical standard difficult for everyone - from university colleagues who must wedge the writing and curation parts in amongst all their other duties, and from my experience as a graduate student or independent researcher - doing it for free and/or at personal expense. If we recognize these components are essential to ethical archaeological practice, they MUST be properly funded.
column28: The first sentence of this doesn't fit with the rest of it. While absolutely we all have responsibility to the next generation, we also have responsibilities to each other in the same generation and older generations. It's not just harassment going forward we need to address, its recognizing harassment that has already happened that has not been addressed or is going on now. I recommend taking that first sentence out or incorporating our responsibilities to the next generation in another principle.

column30:
The ethics reflect the historic development of the discipline and do not meaningfully address Native American concerns. Good faith adherence to NAGPRA, collaboration with tribes and descendent communities, and the recognition that archaeology’s colonialist roots still contribute to the marginalization of Native American, African American, women, and other minorities are not addressed. 

These ethics take as the central concern objects and protection of those objects and data and do not address all of the human challenges in the field, which is a significant failing for an anthropological discipline. Archaeology is anthropology, no?

column10:
I think this is a difficult question to answer because so many ethical dilemmas are entwined. 
Personally I feel that accountability is the most important ethical concern because of the social and political implications for our society and field at large. Anthropology and archaeology are inherently colonial, and I do not think all archaeologists recognize this or necessarily know how to make sure that they are accountable to affected groups (especially indigenous groups) when ideas come into conflict.
That said, I also think that stewardship is a hugely pressing ethical concern. We are often more focused on the in situ archaeological record, including the protection of archaeological sites and the prevention of looting, etc. This is somewhat ironic when many archaeologists don't take the time to fully engage in public education and outreach in an effort to mitigate this problem. As much as in situ preservation is an integral component of stewardship, it is only a portion of the archaeological record and I think overemphasizing this portion of the record is a severe detriment to the stewardship and management of archaeological materials held in collections. Proposals need to include detailed and long-term stewardship/collection management plans.

column14: Wording here can be more robust to go beyond "consult actively with affected group(s)." "Affected groups" is a vague term-- does this refer to descendant communities? the local community? the broader public? Stakeholders can be more clearly defined. Furthermore, consultation does not equal collaboration. Bare minimum legal consultation may not be ethically rigorous enough (e.g., what about Native American groups that are not federally recognized?).

column10: Equitable treatment according to age, ethnicity, gender, and other social distinctions; fair access to heritage and protection of indigenous/traditional heritage rights; preservation and acknowledgement of heritage as a human right; proper treatment, curation, and disposal, where applicable, of archaeological materials and other tangible components of cultural heritage
column12: I think there is a serious issue with believing that the best option will always be in situ preservation when vast amounts of heritage are being destroyed by development, climate change, neglect, and conflict. There needs to be a balance in whether and what to excavate, what to actively preserve, and what to avoid that is recognized and attended to in a judicious, scholarly, and ethical manner that considers to long-term needs of multiple stakeholder groups as well as our shared understanding and experience of the human condition. European scholars recognize that just avoiding archaeology and leaving it in place can result in deterioration and loss of archaeological knowledge at a vast scale and is not demonstrated to be inherently good. Materials of cultural and archaeological significance do not constitute an archaeological record if they are not actually recorded.
column14: Yes, but there needs to be a better and more open and transparent process for doing this. Often, consultation is simply sending letters and paying lip service. Establishing working relationships and trust is key, but also working to develop a new and more enlightened archaeology that can better serve the needs of multiple intellectually and spiritually divergent communities.

column9:
UN Declaration of Human Rights, UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples; UNESCO International Code of Ethics for Dealers in Cultural Property; SHA Code of Ethics; AAA code of ethics; Tribal Cultural Landscape definition (as per BOEM), etc.
I have referred to each of these for multiple purposes;  in the past decade specifically to identify gaps and/or inclusion of indigenous self-identified concerns.  The ability for a dominant and/or privileged population to define the roles, responsibilities, objects, and identity or 'others' is repeatedly demonstrated to erode and undermine sovereignty of Nations.
column10:
the continued use of distancing language the creates positionality of direct and/or indirect power structures (dominate/suppressed).  Past generations of professional, particularly in anthropology and archaeology, by the nature of the academic process create 'specialists' and 'experts on the subject of Other people (their lives, belongings, thoughts, etc.).  The development of Codes of Ethics by- and for- these same experts reaffirms positionality.  Repeatedly the result is an academic Expert makes a declarative statement "X is true!" and the Tribe or decedents of the 'subject people' says, "No, that is not true.  This is true!".  Immediately there is a conflict.  Additionally, 'experts' will chose to research a subject that is taboo to a community and perceived to be inappropriate to be discussed by the uninitiated.  Those communities have no control over the dispersal of that information and are left vulnerable and even sensationalized.  

Today's Tribes and Indigenous nations have withstood plagues, systematic genocide, reservations, and educational systems, all designed to remove them from existence.  there for what is held in community (knowledge, language, understanding, belongings, etc.) is highly intimate and protected.  When specialists flex their expertise it is a dominating act.  When Codes of Ethics are developed one-on-one with the nations with whom you work there will begin to be a balanced understanding of HOW to proceed.  for example, the current code (Intellectual Property) does not recognize that information may originate with a Tribe who may not be comfortable with it being shared outside of community.
